Évaluation publiée le 7 mai 2023
Ctrl Alt Ego is an Immersive Sim reminiscent of System Shock and Prey by the virtue of being set on a space station in the future. But here's a defining twist: this is a poltergeist simulator where you play as a disembodied consciousness, a marooned saboteur EGO, in a constant struggle to keep itself together. Your task is to find resource-effective solutions to a constant stream of creative problems while smuggling yourself through elaborate corporate security checkpoints in the middle of nowhere. This game's world is a sandbox done right, with you being the bucket and the spade. Here, player agency is king.

Setting
The setting incorporates the humorous tone of Douglas Adams and the high-concept narrative of Stanislaw Lem. It's a touching story that poses morbid existential questions and an effortlessly humorous adventure full of cute robots and cerebral gags. The plot is delivered through notes and sparse monologues, dispensed by Dr. Everyman. "A bit cliché English professor", in his own words. Like you, your guide and mentor inhabits various machines. Being but a sack of fragmented memories at the start, you'll find out more than you bargained for by the end. For now, you can only HOP from thing to thing, which, in the long run, should allow you to take ctrl of the station back from some parasite. It's not like you have better plans for your clueless post-matter existence.

Presentation
In appearances, this ain't your art deco, local environments sport a jagged utilitarian design. It grew on me after I had some time to absorb the cosmic contrast between saturated light and thick shadows as well as one tasteful retrofuturistic colour palette. Some might say the game looks technologically inferior, generic, and there's nothing more to it. But I find it ambiguously beautiful. Even if its presentation is a product of limitations, the result is positively Kubrickian, which accurately reflects the sci-fi framework in place.

The world of eccentric automaton freaks sounds cute until you bother them to the point when they start screeching and chasing you. One mistake sends you zipping around clanking corridors in panic, with menacing voices thundering from loudspeakers, professing your inevitable demise. With tensions so high, you need to listen to your surroundings to survive. Instead of music, local environments produce humming and buzzing of machinery. The dwelling robots have names, their beeps and cheeps make each type stand out. You could usually tell whom to expect long before turning a corner.

I appreciate the dev's commitment to include as many accessibility options as possible, yet I'd like to suggest a few additional QoL improvements. For one, the game could use a map. Some locations aren’t that visually distinct and there isn't always an antenna with a bird's-eye view to help with navigation. The hitboxes are accurate, but probably exceedingly so in places, leading to objects in the environment having sticky edges, obstructing movement. Finally, spoiling the overall impression, I've had unwarranted framedrops, especially by the end. Update: it got fixed. Done, now let's unpack the best stuff.

Interfacing
You HOP between hosts by interfacing with their EGO sensors, taking ctrl over robots, opening doors, and signing into security networks. Juggling your hosts is a must, for none of them can do everything. One ctrls like a bumper car, another squeezes in tight spaces, and the other one is a tripod with a beam cannon. Each robot has its clumsy charm. They are distinguished by cute acronyms like MUM, GOD, PUP, breathing personality into the world. I'm sure GOD piqued your interest, but it's uncooperative. BUG 22 would be your main body, your upgradeable toolkit, and your only hope in this world. There's no space to describe every entity, so we'll settle for a holistic example.

The BUG I required was stuck in a locked crate between two BUG-repellent force fields on a module floating in space. I had to HOP into a MUM who was patrolling the module. MUMs are normally used to kill stuff and bypass security, but I only got her through the field to push buttons, unlocking the crate. On the roof of the module, stood a lonely DAD, a sentry that shoots a serialising beam I required. I took ctrl of him and used a SHIFT beam to throw the old git through the field. There, DAD serialised the BUG, which meant that its data got stored in his memory. But the slacker can't do much else, even move, so I used MUM again to push DAD out into space where he printed the BUG for me.

Performing such tricks will soon become second nature. Use your cards right and feel like the smartest bot in the room. Be reckless - and face an out-of-hand cascade, leading to your temporary demise. Instead of immediately losing after your host has been broken or serialised, you get a chance to ctrl something else in the vicinity during your disembodied state. From that position, you can always reprint your property using a BUG Printer device or HOP into a thing that serialised you and rescue the body. Hold your horses, though! Killing or seizing stuff comes at a price. Your options are vast, but restricted by certain resources.

Egonomics
Time to talk Egonomics. Just a few things to wrap your head around first. There're 6 pickups: Juice (fuel for abilities), batteries (HP), EGO fragments, Worms, Disks, and MEMs. Use a MEM with an Augmentation Terminal to raise your HOP speed, make enemies less observant, etc. Put a Disc in a BUG to install a permanent ability of your choice, then find Worms to upgrade those. Using that system, equip your BUG with different arms, rocket boosters, invisibility, and other cool stuff. With that, go to town or go virtual, reprint yourself on the other side of an obstacle course or a fence, drop bombs, and fly away.

All hosts have EGO ratings, to ctrl them you need to spend an according amount of EGO that can be found in the wild or by hopping into certain stuff that stores it. There's more than enough EGO scattered around the place, but not so much that you could mindlessly cut through the majority of predicaments, overriding and destroying everything. The going gets tough by the midgame, save up. I was always barely scraping by, yet that didn't diminish the fun I had, making me find unorthodox solutions to problems instead of throwing EGO at them. Granted, the EGO poverty stemmed from me stupidly doing just that when I had plenty.

There's enough Juice if you don't always go guns blazing. Despite some great gunplay with powerful feedback and headshots in slow motion, brute force lacks unless used along with other skills. For what's a shotgun blast when you can shift things around at will, reprint yourself to skip obstacles, or turn any object into a bomb? Even if you crave total carnage, you'll still find a variety of possible abilities irreplaceable. Something new always impedes your progress, it's a challenging ordeal. But most of all - a gratifying endeavour. If you like imaginative secrets hidden across interconnected environments, you've come to the right place.

End
I opted for the second hardest difficulty because it gives enemies recharging health without making them too tanky. I wanted to keep the option to go Rambo. Like Rambo, I had to sneak and plan my ambushes carefully to single out my prey or break several robots in quick succession. I failed a lot. I don't mind, but that difficulty setting may seem too frantic for some. Keep this in mind in case you want a relaxed playthrough. Mine wasn't, but I enjoyed every minute of it. The colossal ambition behind this sleeper hit is staggering. Its fun conundrums came to be unique and captivating. At the end of the day, Ctrl Alt Ego is a contemplative experience that ambushes you with its penetrating narrative and sharp design.

My curator Big Bad Mutuh

Évaluation publiée le 24 juillet 2022
Game presents you with a simulated environment, where almost every element is interactible. It presents you a sandbox, and then offers numerous tools to achieve your goals whichever way you want. It's reminiscent of immersive sims like System Shock, but instead of focusing on rpg-like character progression (the way most modern sims went) it leans more into puzzle-game-like territory, with one major difference - the focus is not, (like in for example Portal) to figure out the one right solution. The game pushes you to employ your creativity instead, making it, i feel, the most similar to Thief 1/Thief 2 in how it encourages you to experiment with tools at your disposal. The most prominent is the ability to possess objects - both enemies, and things like computers or doors, with possessions giving you different opportunities.

There is still a character progression system in place, in form of BUG-s, multipurpose bots you can upgrade with collectible floppy disks, giving them new tools such as ability to fly or shoot, a tool that works as a vacuum cleaner, or telekinesis. This system can however be safely ignored if one wishes to do so. There is even an achievement for finishing the game with no BUG upgrades - open ended level design means there are a lot of ways to achieve your goals with minimal BUG usage.

I really enjoy the voice acting and writing - it's both funny (my favourite so far being "wrong kind of emu" pun) and engaging (for example, every possessed object can introduce themselves to you, giving you both engaging bits of worldbuilding and presenting a kind of personality)

It's worth mentioning how the game rewards exploration. A lot of optional places require you to be creative with how you get inside, and reward you with collectibles that actually feel rewarding - each one has their use, unlike with collectibles in some mainstream games. There are already mentioned floppy disks, but also EGO points you can use for possessing enemies, and many more i won't list here.

Évaluation publiée le 21 janvier 2023
Probably the best immersive sim of 2022 was made by a team of two devs. Ctrl Alt Ego has everything one's looking for in the genre:
  • Wide range of available playstyles: sneaky, stabby, hacky, mind controlly, shooty.
  • Solid amount of skills and perks with a range of customization options.
  • Graphics straight out of the early 2000s to remind one of the genre classics.
  • Dystopian future on a derelict space station.
  • Early Doctor Who aesthetics.
  • 15-20ish hour campaign that doesn't overstay its welcome. Later levels offer fun and spoilery gimmicks.
  • Viable option of accepting one's screwups and carrying on with the consequences instead of rapid save scumming (which is also an option)
On a more important note, the game offers 44 achievements each with its own unique cat photo used as an art thumbnail. You heard that right, folks: 44 cute cat photos for the low, low price of $19.99 or your regional equivalent! It's a barkin' bargain!

Évaluation publiée le 13 aout 2022
I'm completely blown away that this entire thing was made by just two people. I normally don't review games, but since I completely lucked into finding this game I'm leaving a review in hopes that it helps more people find it.

This was a surprisingly long (my first playthrough was a hair over 13 hours), absolutely incredible immersive sim wrapped up in a funny "you're in a computer" style world. The core loop has you transferring your consciousness through various entities around the world to gain access to new areas/defeat enemies/read "eyepads"/etc, but you'll spend most of your time in a robot called Bug 22. They're the only bug with a disk drive and therefore the only one that can accept upgrades.

The upgrades are all available from the start so it's up to you to decide which you want first. I know I missed a few upgrade disks in my playthrough but I still managed to get every upgrade. You can also power up each upgrade with "worms" to reduce to cost to use or increase the effectiveness or even otherwise enhance the upgrades.

Aesthetically the game isn't going to win any awards. It's consistent and everything fits within this world, but don't expect AAA sub-surface scattering and ray tracing. Don't let the visuals distract you from the absolutely incredible gameplay, however.

The story was surprisingly good, touching on the nature of consciousness without taking itself too seriously. There were a lot of inside-programming/IT jokes (merging commits, visiting the cloud via port 80, bad password management, etc.). I also really enjoyed how the controls actually were part of the joke: in order to take "control" of other entities, you push CTRL; if you want to "shift" objects around, you push SHIFT; to download an "alternate" version of yourself (aka teleport) you use ALT.

I really appreciated how if you were thorough you could discover many different solutions to the same problem. For example to get through a locked door, you might find a vent that only a certain type of robot can fit through to get around it, but the vent is blocked by a heavy box that you can move (if you have the right upgrade) or destroy (if you have the right upgrade, or you could take control of a hostile robot to use their weapon to remove the box), or you can use the grate on the ceiling (if you have boosters), or you could take control of a camera and jump around from entity to entity to try to get an angle on the door lock and open it from the other side.

According to the achievements the entire game should be playable without any upgrades, completely pacifist, or ghost. I was not skilled enough to do any of those, but it's a sign of a quality immersive sim that those are all available.

I'll definitely be coming back to this to try levels again with different tools.

tl;dr: I wholeheartedly recommend this to anyone who is a fan of the immersive sim genre.

Évaluation publiée le 15 aout 2023
As an obnoxious immersive sim enthusiast I learned of this game a while ago but kept sleeping on it as I did with other immersive sims like Dishonored 2. After I burned out hauling cargo for 100 hours straight I decided I'd finally pick this one up since some folks in my imsim sphere have likened it to the OG Deus Ex which was an intriguing prospect. How does it fare?

Well, this might be one of the best imsims I've played in recent memory on a purely mechanical level. The core mechanic of jumping from machine to machine using the power of possession in such large sandbox-esque levels, coupled with various tools you can equip to your core 'Bug' along with upgrades in the form of 'Worms' creates a whole realm of possible solutions to the scenarios laid out in front of you. I was having an absolute blast flexing my brain trying to figure out how to solve the puzzles, and marvelling at my own creativity when I come up with something completely outlandish which as various notes in the game will tell, was definitely intended by the developer. If you think you broke the game, you probably didn't (unless you clipped through a wall and fell out of bounds which I think is probably one of the few things that wasn't intended)

As for the story, it gets very philosophical and I'm not smart enough to fully understand the ideas talked about in the game, since I tend to think more mechanically in games and don't have much luck analysing a story beyond "good guy good, bad guy bad." I also really enjoyed the music in the game because hilariously, every interactable object in this game has its own theme music and some tracks in particular were so good I bought the soundtrack. The humour in this game is very British, and the main character you interact with throughout the story seems very likeable and has an interesting backstory, but I would recommend you just play through the game to experience this because it definitely should be played.

This game also presents an interesting idea behind the whole concept of an immersive sim, in that they can essentially be seen as puzzle games where a puzzle may have various different answers. Do you shotgun the problem, do you drill the problem into tiny pieces, do you telekinetically throw the problem around the room until its solved? Do you possess the problem and hop between different aspects of the problem until you reach the solution? Just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ play this game then because if you see yourself as a creative problem solver in games then this is definitely for you.

So yeah, S tier immersive sim and hugely underrated, huge recommendation to those who enjoy the genre.

Évaluation publiée le 30 décembre 2022
Initially intriguing and entertaining concept which becomes repetitive and miserable towards the end of the game. I was really rushing to finish it towards the end because I knew if I put it down, I would never pick it up again and finish it. I did finish it on moderate difficulty. In the end it was a lot less than I was expecting in terms of gameplay.

From hearing positive reviews of the game and seeing the trailers, what I was expecting was a lot different than what I got...

Be aware it is a rather linear, level-based progression through levels with puzzles that have clearly designed-for solutions. It was a lot more like a puzzle game than something more open-ended and dynamic. Yes, there are numerous approaches to puzzles and numerous ways to deal with enemies but I didn't really see this as a contributor to the fun of the game. Each of the options I tried never felt that fun to me, sometimes were even frustrating. Once your build has gone down a certain path you will generally be doing that for the rest of the game, too. The game didn't seem to reward or encourage variety and experimentation outside of the player getting bored.

The premise of the game makes it seem like you might be controlling and coordinating a variety of unique devices, possibly coordinating them in parallel like a hybrid RTS, maybe eventually amassing an army, but that's not at all what it is. You will basically be spending most of your time controlling only one bot, Bug 22, as that's the bot that receives all of the upgrades. You never have multiple Bugs that have upgrades active at once, any other Bugs you find basically do nothing. Coordinating multiple things is basically not feasible and pointless since your bot is strong enough to take everything on its own. Other than that actual controllable units, it is basically just static devices you possess to gain ego points, view an area, or read text. Generally, nothing you control needs to be brought between areas. No point as there will always be more.

If there was more to do with those static devices that would be cool, but as it stands the game might honestly be better without them.

As for the controllable units other than Bug 22, basically there is just PUP, MUM, and DAD. Pup is for small vents and annoyingly has to be carried in hand as a physical object - you can't "store" him in inventory and take him with you. Especially annoying as he clacks against everything and you get stuck on objects when trying to carry him around. Just trust me, you will learn to hate it. Mum moves and shoots and was kill on sight for me, the ability it has to freeze and let you carry enemies was never something I needed. Dad is basically a turret but can also zap objects to store them and materialize them which I used in a few puzzles. And that's basically it for controllable units. After I was comfortable enough with melee, mum and dad were basically always kill on sight. And none of them really act autonomously once you control them so they are basically siting ducks.

I ended up going with a melee build, using the disassembler (drill) and VaQ to efficiently defeat enemies. It worked and I was able to conserve a lot of resources and progress quickly, but I had often frustrating issues with melee hit registration where enemies weren't taking damage when I was drilling right on them (this was mostly an issue with the flying enemies). Once I saw the various options for dealing with enemies this seemed like the least annoying, and even then it was annoying. The melee can destroy enemies before they even aggro you, and the VaQ replenishes your oil and health so you can keep meleeing. At the end I had amassed several unspent skill points which would let me unlock new abilities and I didn't even use them as nothing seemed interesting or useful and what I was doing worked fine. I stayed FAR away from any ability that looked like I might need to carry and throw things as that doesn't work well AT ALL in this game's physics engine and cramped rooms. If the rooms were a bit more spacious I could see those things working out better, but alas.

Combat is annoying but easier than trying to sneak around. Easier to kill everything first generally. You will either spend ego to use enemies to destroy other enemies (or ctrl them to make them not a threat) or destroy them directly via combat from your main bug.

I had some frustrating repetitive moments of dying or getting spotted and reloading. The game tells you you can just spend ego to resurrect your bot but why bother when you could just reload, plus you don't know how much ego you should be saving.

Ego jumping gets really tedious, fast. You need to ego jump to open doors and to save and to collect the primary resource of the game. You do this a LOT. These things should've just been a button press.

The game is sometimes inconsistent with what must be done via ego jumping vs switches/buttons. I kept forgetting that switches were even a thing, which led to me getting stuck on some sections as I was looking for things which were ego-jumpable

The game does a bad job in some places with signifiers. A lot of the "challenge" of making progress is just noticing things that you need to progress and the game makes them annoyingly hard to notice at times, resulting in tedious pixel hunting. Tiny switches which have to be manually pressed despite 90% of things being activated by ego jumping, ego-jumpable things which don't highlight in ego mode despite looking right at them, and vent grates or openings which are really dark and not highlighted by the level design. In some cases there are things that visually look like vent openings but which are not openable.

Performance is really bad on the last area, which you will spend quite a bit of time in. Getting frequent sub-15 FPS in certain areas. I wanted to spend more time exploring this area but performance was so bad I didn't bother.

About 1/3 into the game you have basically seen all there is in terms of gameplay outside of some additional abilities you can get which basically just give you different ways to destroy enemies and then some really annoying flying enemies introduced later that kill you near instantly if the physics engine decides to not be on your side. Those enemies really aren't fun to deal with and can't even be possessed and due to how much they move around, seem to screw with the melee hit detection.

I would've been totally fine if the game ended like 2 chapters earlier. But then it just kept going on and on and there was nothing there in the game that inspired me to want to keep playing other than the hope of some new stuff or variety that never came.

With all these issues, there is plenty the game does right. My favorite aspect is the quirky dialogue, writing and story, and the design of the different units is cute as well. But in terms of the moment to moment gameplay, I started to get sick of it halfway through.

Évaluation publiée le 25 septembre 2022
Immersive sims are such a rarity to find and are only recently having resurgence via the indie scene. Ctrl Alt Ego however already feels like it can stand out from the old and new due to what if focuses on.

Combat and/or stealth tend to be the bread and butter for this genre (Thief, System Shock, Deus Ex, etc.). While CAE offers systems to accommodate both play styles, every encounter is designed around feeling more puzzle oriented as CAE's big gameplay mechanic involves the player being able to take control of objects and robots around the environment and swap between one another for different uses. Your "main" robot of sorts known as the "BUG", also gains an assortment of unlockable programs (aka, Deus Ex styled augmentations) and each having a respective sub skills to spec into (all of which is dependent on how much the player explores the levels and find collectibles for upgrading). All of this is wrapped up on top of simple but effective resource management systems around a "juice" meter (how much energy you have to use one of your many programs), "EGO" (a cost requirement to possess enemy robots), and a fully physics based environment with many throwable objects.

The game fully offers lethal and non-lethal solutions to anything in the game which not only affects the build the player goes for but also a long term mentality around solving puzzles. A lethal player wouldn't have to worry about wandering enemies but will have to deal with the constant need to search for resources to refill juice and health around the environment as well as losing any possession opportunities a different robot can give. A non-lethal play style gives the player more opportunities for subterfuge and saving on juice but at the potential cost of using more EGO for possession and needing to pre-plan a lot more around the environment to minimize direct confrontations (such as setting up walls of barrels and crates to hide enemy sight lines). This isn't even considering factors such as a stealthy or a rush kind of approach, a completionist mentality, or even self-inflicted challenges such as a no program run (meaning you have to entirely rely on the environment to go through levels). Changing up playstyles and builds really feels like a different experience instead of just a different coat of paint here.

There's a ton more to compliment about the game than just this aspect (the claustrophobic yet open level design, the dry humor, the mission select that allows players to easily revisit chapters they completed to test out different playstyles without needing to start up the entire campaign again, QoL like being able to know what collectibles are leftover in an area before leaving, the fact that every achievement are cat pictures, etc.) but the aspect above is what I wanted to emphasize the most because the advertising might lead people to thinking it's just a game with a neat gimmick around it. It's a game with about as much depth as any other immersive sim to compare it to and it would be a shame for a game this good to not get the proper recognition it deserves. Especially at the price point relative to the amount of content and replayability on display, this is something any immersive sim fan and puzzle game fan should try out.

Do yourself a favor and buy this game.

Évaluation publiée le 8 septembre 2022
Great game, holds up well against other imsims. Really flexed my creativity, and it wasn't until I realized that I wasn't going for a pacifist run that I really opened up.

Goodness, I already feel nostalgic for the early levels.

If you're playing on Strict, enemies regen their health fairly quickly, so it's a game of "you come at the king, you best not miss." Which actually isn't THAT difficult; you can do a lot of damage with a fair bit of preparation. This ain't your pappy's wave shooter, you gotta scout out your enemies, see if they've got any supporting healers, hack the healers, isolate your prey. Lock them in a transparent room of containers. May be tempted to scratch at the walls, make them know fear, but that'll activate their onboard shields, making it that much harder. No, the prison is the FINAL step in executing these lesser beings. The moment they glanced even the slightest hint that something was wrong was the last moment of their pathetic life. They bump into the box to get around it, boom. Box blows up, rest of the walls blow up, they blow up, you blow up, you load a save and take a few steps back beforehand, they blow up, you rush in with a shotgun and cap their head clean off, then cannibalize their "corpse" for that sweet, sweet fuel.

Lesser difficulties you'll have great success chucking boxes and explosive barrels at people, no tricks, edit: on strict+, I said they'd heal up by the time you can grab a second barrel, but that's only if they detect you first. I've been having a lot more success just by planning the tosses, timing them when they look away.

I also ended with well over 200 ego stashed away, so as long as you're not "wasting" it with excessive revives, you'll not need to fret too hard over currency. All in all, this is a great game worth your time and worth your mind.

Évaluation publiée le 28 décembre 2022
This game was actually surprising to me as by the end I realized it became my favorite Immersive Sim out of the many I've played.

Starting off the gameplay is really diverse and honestly impressive on how you can go about doing things. You as the player are an Ego who can control any device with a sensor, therefore using it as your host, and that can help you scout out what is in a room, or use an enemy robot to infiltrate in places without triggering any hostiles and maybe even taking out your enemies before you move in your bug. Speaking of which, Bug 22 is your main host as it is the only host you can upgrade utilizing disks, those upgrades can range from ego (a resource you need to ctrl other robots, locked doors, keypads, etc.) sucker, aeronautics that allow you fly, shotgun, etc. which all offer you even more ways of tackling the situations the game gives you, furthermore, these uprgades can be improved using Worms that you can find plenty across the games areas.

Level design is good and really reminds me of Prey and System Shock games (one of the best immersive sims imo), as well as the whole game reminds me of them. It is separated into 3 facilities all with their zones which you load into, and there are various ways to move through these zones which may even let you avoid any kind of conflict at all, which helps you save your resources. Something else that surprised me was the length, I was scared that it'd be a quick game but I was surprised to say that I spent a good 12 hours in-game which was enjoyable from start to finish.

The story is unique I'd say, you can uncover points of the plot aswell as foreshadowings at any order basically. You also have a man named Dr. David Everyman who guides you across the CRS and tells you information about a few things, but not everything, to obtain more information you must read the note pads scattered across the games all telling you different aspects of the place you're in aswell as the people that once were there. Something I'd like to add is that the antagonist really reminds me of SHODAN if it's voice were of a male, and it really sounds intimidating and imposing although too loud.

Overall, I'd say this is the best game I've played this year and I can tell the developer(s) really put effort into this to make it feel like an authentic Immersive Sim taking inspiration from its predecessors my only complaint really is that the antagonist sounds too loud and the only other issue I've had were cases of the Bug being outside the map when I ctrl'd it after going far away from it aswell as when downloading it too close to a corner. I'd also like to point out how active the developer, Mindthunk, is be it in their twitter or the steam forum of the game, responding to every question a player may have about the game and even taking their suggestions for future updates, I believe that is the sign of a great developer who listen to it's players that want to improve the game. I give it a 10/10 and definitely a GOTY for me

This game should be way more popular!
+ The level of freedom is like nothing else I've ever seen, it's not just "you can go stealth or berserk" type crap - you're given a goal and it's totally up to you how you achieve it
+ Great humor reminding me of Wheatley from Portal 2
+ Many immersive sims have a problem with save scumming. In Ctrl Alt Ego, death is a part of the experience, and it's so masterfully crafted you wouldn't want it any other way - you never get mad when you die as it always opens up even more possibilities.
+ Multiple shortcuts and other secrets to uncover
+ Cats

The only issue I had was with performance, which wasn't the best the last time I tried it, so I had to turn resolution down from 3440x1440 to 2560x1080 to get good framerates... but a performance update hit Steam just 2 days ago, so it may very well be better now. Finally an excuse for me to play again :)

Just go play it!! You won't be disappointed I promise!

Edit: indeed performance is WAY better after the update!

Évaluation publiée le 23 juillet 2022
My playtime on record undersells how long I've played. I spent maybe 6-8 hours on the Demo before release. This game is SO good, it rocks my world, I need to set aside more time to play it. I'm trying so hard not to ramble because I got a veritable flood of happy brain chemicals from the game. TLDR this game has all the features I want it to have, I consider it a diamond in the rough.

The core mechanic, "hopping" between hosts, is awesome. It may look like a psychedelic trip in the screenshots but it's quite smooth. You use this to find all sorts of vantage points and solve puzzles, resulting in great "a-ha!" moments. It goes hand-in-hand with the exploration that is also incredibly rewarding.

The exploration is great. The levels are big, but not overwhelmingly so. You are not picking up everyone's crap like in a Bethesda game, but the environment is just as interactable. There are about 4 types of items for you to find: your hp/energy pickups, which I have no trouble keeping topped up all the time; and disks and worms, which you spend on permanent upgrades. Each of these upgrade "paths", there are around 8 I think, promises a unique power for you to use. I went straight for the flight power which later upgrades to include a "ramming" ability, which is pretty fun.

Physics objects are all over the place for you to use in creative ways. (i.e. for navigation or combat) It reminds me of my limited knowledge of Half Life. Don't be put off by the cliche of "x meets y" when the store page references Portal, there really is a strong brain-bending element to this game that rewards ingenuity. You know how in Zelda you get a key item every dungeon and then all the remaining puzzles are obvious? Well, this game's approach to environmental puzzles and permanent upgrades is like a more clever spin on that, since the various tools can be used for various problems, it's not a 1-to-1.

There are pacifist, killer, and total stealth objectives. There is a clear outline of how to achieve these challenges (actually the tutorial system and new player experience is good overall) and a tracker at the end of each level, so when you reach the tracker, you can go back and get the bits you missed. I am REALLY curious to see some challenge runs, maybe that mix-n-match the playstyle challenge with other restrictions. You really can "play the game your way", something that is often promised but almost never delivered.

Your goal is basically to clear the level by reaching various sub-objectives. But despite being a game full of robots, there is nothing robotic about this, as you are constantly treated to humorous quips from the (somewhat sentient?) bots you inhabit. There is some really good voice acting that helps brings the world to life. We get humorous names for technology in this world like DADs and CATs. Though the themes are kinda serious, the experience is whimsical too. I got tired of being an edgy assassin boi in Dishonored/Deus Ex, or being deeply alone with the dead in Prey 2017. No, this game has more room for lightheartedness in its fun, I think.

I came for the gameplay, stayed for that plus everything else. It is obviously gameplay-first so I was impressed by the depth of everything beyond those technical aspects. This is clearly a passion project, and I'm in awe of it, I hope maybe I can make something similarly inspiring one day. Give it a try if you like its contemporaries or you are just curious, you won't regret it!

**EDIT the Hop animation can be toned down if it's too intense. dev has been great with adding features and bugfixes in patch.
 
noahgamblez

Évaluation publiée le 26 juillet 2022
A Fantastic Game, With Some Rough Edges

EDIT: I have been in contact with the developer over the suggestions and bugs that i experienced and while we had understandable disagreements over some, all of them have been at least discussed. the suggestion list has been updated to show what has and has not changed

In short, Ctrl Alt Ego is a great game with a unique concept, executed brilliantly, and a worthy buy. The body hopping mechanic combined with its immersive sim elements allows for the player to make up creative solutions to problems on the fly, with each robot's strengths and weaknesses complimenting one another to ensure that there is no one solution that becomes a dominant strategy (at least for now in my playthrough)

The level design, while not starting off on its best foot, really starts hitting high points as soon as you get through the levels that were available in the demo, with a ton of really clever moments, especially when attempting to play pacifist.

However, some design decisions and/or oversights have left me annoyed at times, and while they are in no way dealbreakers, i feel like i should at least point them out, in a hope that the developer gives an update to the game to make any future players lives just that bit better

For context, i am attempting a pacifist/ghost playthough, very slight spoilers ahead, mostly mechanical not story


THE ISSUES/GRIEVANCES THAT I HAVE HAD, ORDERED BY HOW EASY THEY COULD BE SOLVED

- The stats screens are treated like the unimportant bots in that you can only hop to them when very close, which is quite annoying when you just accidentally exploded a room full of bug traps and are trying to find out if you added to your bots broken counter (FIXED)
- Letting the player know that attempting to use a locked door, while controlling a bot that has the key, wont actually let you unlock the door will help alleviate the disappointment for when they actually try (FIXED, Controlling dads that have keys allow you to open locked doors)
- Bug bots do not explode when thrown or have object thrown at them, but explode when landed on by non bugs, which is an annoying lack of consistency ( DISCUSSED, was me being dumb)
- There appear to be some holes in the sound design, most notably being DAD's that make AFAIK no sound at all when idle, even when turning, leading to too many situations of me going into a room looking around for friendlies to get ego from, and next thing i know theres a DAD beam hitting me in the back. on top of that, it would be really really helpful if the enemies made some kind of windup sound indicating when theyre gonna change direction, because there is otherwise no way to tell when an enemy is going to turn if they are turning from a dead stop (cameras, DAD's, etc) (DISCUSSED, on the todo list (?))
- The delay on changing direction when controlling MOM's is really annoying, and doesnt even make sense when changing direction by moving the camera holds no penalty (FIXED)
- The hexagonal projection given off by cameras seems unhelpful at letting you determine the actual boundaries of its vision (DISCUSSED, unchanged, not much of a real issue)
- The wobbling of your aim when firing a MOM's beam feels unfair when your enemies fire at you with perfect aim (FIXED)
- Please include the bother meter for enemies while controlling unsafe bots. I think that the scrambled ego perk has some effect on unsafe bots, but am unsure. regardless, there have been a couple too many times where i am in line of sight of a bot, they arent reacting to me, i think im in the clear, and then all of a sudden they can see me. (DISCUSSED not planned to change, but noted)
- When engaging with an enemy, there have been a couple of occasions where it just has not been obvious that they are being healed by a matterboy which means you cannot win. I would suggest a change to the enemy energy bar that shows not only are they currently being healed by a matterboy, but that there is a matterboy nearby pre fight, so you dont get into a dad fight only to find out that you literally cannot win (DISCUSSED, not planned to change, but added the feature that lets you put matterboys in auto mode)
- Virtual program counts 'warning' as 'being attacked', which again was disappointing to find out. I would actually suggest splitting the upgrade that lets you go invisible while under attack into 2 parts; a 1 worm upgrade that lets you go invisible while enemy is in 'warning' state, and a 2 worm upgrade that lets you go invisible while being actually attacked (FIXED, no longer considers warning as being attacked)
- The ego drain function is way too expensive, and is basically useless stock. Keeping it as is while making it cheaper would be broken tho, so i propose that a new upgrade tree be added that determines how much ego you can drain off a single target, starting at 10% of their starting ego, then going 25% 50% and 65%, with the worm cost of the whole program readjusted to accommodate (DISCUSSED, not changed, but ego drain being faster being considered)
- Picking up objects feels kind of unfinished, and for whatever reason the thing your holding will just occasionally decide its not being held anymore , which is really not fun when the thing youre holding is an impact explosive (FIXED)
- Even with filters, selecting what bot to control while in ego mode is just Not A Good Experience. More often than not it treats where youre looking as mere suggestion that it can prompty ignore while it selects a bot thats halfway off the screen and 100 meters away. On top of that friendly bots are often completely ignored when not exclusively filtering for them, and even then it takes a lot for the game to decide to reveal some of them (FIXED for the most part, selecting object more biased towards the middle of the screen)
- On both of the levels available in the demo, i attempted to do a clean sweep for the achievement, but in both cases could not find 1 ego remaining in the level, and going around and around a level with a fine tooth comb leads me to believe that either this is a bug and i did find everything, or the final object in both levels is unreasonably difficult to find. In either case, a nice quality of life improvement would be giving the emu itself a skilltree that let you narrow down the remaining bits of friendly ego, and possibly other collectables. (DISCUSSED a sort of unlockable ego radar for future playthroughs is on the todo list)
- Remote Debugging could have done with a complete redesign. Launch control sufferes a bit from this too, but Remote Debugging really feels like a level from a demo that was made months before the rest of the levels and never got revisited. Ideally the first levels of the game should be the last levels you make, as it means youre putting your best foot forward. But having a linear corridor with the same stationary enemy over and over again is not exactly what i would call 'your best foot forward', which is really a shame because like i mentioned this game past that point has some REALLY good level design, and it would be a shame if someone got turned off from the demo because the last moment they had in it was just going through a corridor and never picking up the full release (DISCUSSED understandably not going to happen)

To anyone that got through this to the end, please note that none of these are real deal breakers (and now most of these have been fixed!), and that the game easily justifies the price (especially during the opening week sale) and i am Absolutely having fun with it, its just that as a hobbyist imsim game dev myself (coming soon 2090), i cant help but notice some things that i felt the need to speak up on, if only to try to help

Évaluation publiée le 19 septembre 2022
100% yes!

This is a delightful immersive sim, featuring a compelling variety of abilities and approaches, a 'fail forward' design (though you can use traditional save/load if you want!), and a charming, idiosyncratic setting. Exploration and completionism are rewarded with more resources and ability development, but a more focused approach can certainly succeed as well; with skillful play all critical challenges are completable without ANY upgrades or special resources. There are several difficulty levels to provide a substantially tougher experience, or a more dialed back, relaxing romp.

Special care has been taken in the design to specifically support the classic immersive sim trinity of violence, pacifism, or stealth, with special achievements available for completing a level with any of these playstyles. Helpful scoreboards within the game let you know how many resources are left to find, how many enemies are left to defeat, how many times you've been detected, etc. Again, none of this is mandatory for completing the game and I found for my first run-through that a constant mix of styles was most fun for me.

The abilities available have great variety and may be learned in any order. If you want your very first special power to be invisibility, that can be your first upgrade. Flight? Teleportation? Implosion bombs? Telekinesis? These and other skills are slowly learned one by one and beg to be used in creative combination to evade, destroy, or turn threats over to your side. Additionally, each upgrade can itself be improved with sufficient resources; your melee drill might gain increased reach, or your shield might become more energy efficient. You can focus on improving just a few upgrades to high levels, boost everything for more versatility, or eschew them altogether for a real challenge.

Ctrl Alt Ego's central gameplay mechanic is also its most unique: the power to possess and ctrl almost any unit or electronic item in the game! If you can't open a locked door, perhaps you can project your consciousness through it and take command of a security camera on the other side. Then, from that vantage point, examine the room visually and dominate an enemy robot previously hidden, and use its access to open the door for you, or even achieve your objective without opening the door at all! Often, enemies of superior strength can be turned against one another to great effect. Of course, each approach has its own costs as well as advantages.

The pacing of the game is wonderful, with varying tasks to perform, several enemy types to learn, convoluted level design that demands player attention to navigate, and a story at once humorous, tragic, and bizarre. I won't spoil anything here, but there were a few turns taken that surprised me, and made me respect the writing and design even more than already expressed.

The main campaign at the default difficulty level took me about 25 hours to finish, with a "trying to find the all secrets but not being too crazy about it" level of completionism. I can always go back and play again at higher difficulty if I REALLY want to find every last worm and ego fragment. For now, I'm very satisfied with my playthrough and the length felt just right. The game took a good solid investment to finish but never wore out its welcome.

This is a masterfully crafted imsim and if what I've said here sounds at all interesting to you, don't wait for a sale. $20 is a steal for such a challenging, engaging, entertaining, and substantial piece of work.
 
Zombra

Évaluation publiée le 22 février 2023
Наткнулся на мега-позитивный обзор этого immersive sim у Charlatan Wonder и решил сразу купить, потому что хороших immersive sim днем с огнем не сыщешь, как говорится.

Действительно необычный проект, который идет по знакомым тропам immersive-геймплея, внося при этом очень свою механику перемещения между объектами/персонажами.

Самое близкое с чем могу сравнить - это первый System Shock, в первую очередь за счет механик апгрейда своего персонажа (единственное тут вроде выключать апгрейды нельзя, если купил то до конца).
Ну и любой другой immersive sim с подходом "вот уровень, цель ясна, приступай в любой последовательности и любыми методам".

Круто, самобытно, постоянно интригует, хочется искать секретные проходы, хочется попробовать все апгрейды, все какое-то значимое, игровой процесс ощутимо меняется вместе с тем как ты сам понимаешь "как можно играть", и как прокачиваешь персонажа.

Единственное, как по мне, так в концовке стало слишком много угроз и врагов на карте, и только поэтому в этот раз я игру точно не закончу. Жаль, потому что финальная локация вот прям тру, много этажей, полная свобода перемещения.
Ну и будто карты не хватает.

14 часов полностью погруженным в процесс я от нее получил.

Évaluation publiée le 23 juillet 2022
本测评已部分过时，且作者因为无法承受3D眩晕已无力继续完成游戏补完测评，如有了解游戏的需求请参阅sinnoware的测评。

目前玩完了第三章，因为太晕先写个评测，优点：
1.综合类机关图多，解法丰富。
2.主控机体能力可拓展性还算不错，dad最好；bug看起来能力多但比较平庸；pup的作用可替代性比较强，也有作为无聊的唯一解出现的时候；mum看起来后期能组成军队？这个有点意思。

但缺乏测试反馈带来了相当多细节上的问题：
1.滑行移动方式和粗劣的光影渲染的组合造就了前所未有的3D眩晕
2.fault能力制造的炸弹是否爆炸可能取决于碰撞动量，但动量阈值调得太低了以至于经常出现被门卡住——炸弹爆炸、慢速行进——炸弹爆炸等影响游戏体验的情况
3.第三章的关卡设计相比于一二章极速下滑。一二章虽然仍存在空间可推断性弱、缺少破序结构等问题，但仍是具有复杂结构的连通迷宫，而第三章就是一个标准的寻物环形潜行关卡，寻物还做得非常线性
4.过度强调跃迁这一核心能力的作用。但滥用跃迁在有些互动元件上是画蛇添足，比如电梯按钮；又缺乏更深层次的互动，比如移动可跃迁元件搭建网络（目前只知道使用dad移动其他机器人一种方法）
5.相当多的互动元件无拓展能力，只是收集ego和视野寻物的工具——但必须强调的是，大家来找茬并不有趣，收集ego也不应当作为玩家游玩时脑子里思考的目标。
6.可怕的地图加载频率，只有半条命可堪比拟。
7.对了，补充一点：如无限制距离飞行之类的暴力解法给得太早甚至可以说是第一章的强制需求（竖直梯子爬不上去得靠飞行飞上去也有点......虽说从合理性上讲可以观察到bug的足部是悬浮推进器不能爬梯子很合理，但这也太反直觉了，第一章找到回转路线发现是原本爬不上去的梯子时我甚至觉得有点搞笑）。虽然很理解作者想让不同类型的玩家都拥有良好体验的良苦用心，但如果你想让玩家多思考不同解法就应当尽可能减少这类暴力解的数量。
掠食的反组引力球就是个很典型的例子：当没有反组引力球又想推开杠杆III需求的货物时会怎么办？哦，原来可以试着用燃气瓶炸开货物或用杠杆II去砸。虽然它也给多了但至少是手上一般不超过10个的消耗品，得精打细算考虑着用。超低蓝条消耗飞行真可以说是一力破万法了，拿到这个能力后搬运箱子搭通道、找斜面、甚至部分区域的视觉跃迁之类解法统统都失去了寻找的意义

不写了我先去吐一会儿，什么时候想起来再玩吧。
 
碎空星

Évaluation publiée le 2 aout 2022
I've been meaning to write a review of this game since I finished the tutorial level and immediately knew I had found something special, but wanted to spend some time engaging with the systems and narrative so I could be sure I was able to really, properly articulate how spectacular Ctrl Alt Ego really is. I think I'm about halfway (or maybe closer to three-fourths) through the game now, and I feel fairly confident in calling this game a genuine landmark in the long-neglected, amorphously defined immersive sim genre. Immersive sims are complex and difficult (which is probably why they're so rare) so I think it also bears pointing out the scale of the developer's accomplishment doing this as an indie dev on their own. The amount of care, effort, and creativity that went into this experience is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ staggering, and the level of polish feels consonant with something a multi-person, well-budgeted studio would put out.

In Ctrl Alt Ego, you're yourself - an identity that exists discretely, and, presumably, a sui generis manifestation of an actual individual (though questions about the substance and materiality of the player's identity is woven throughout the systems and narrative) in a post-singularity world dominated by a robotics company that manufactures devices disembodied egos such as yourself can - or must - inhabit and control. Mechanically, this manifests itself via a possession system that is reminiscent of the Dishonored skill scaled up and extrapolated to it's logical conclusion, where you float around, jumping from one controllable object/robot/item to another in order to interact with the environment. It sounds pretty straightforward and in many ways it is, and, in the tradition of the great immersive sims of eras past, it can be as complex as your level of engagement; you can elegantly, stealthily, and harmlessly complete challenges or brute-force your way through with your weaponized BUG.

To that end, Ctrl Alt Ego offers the player a pretty wide range of skills and instruments designed to navigate the fairly large, wonderfully layered levels. While you'll inhabit a number of different robots (there are four that move around and have major utility) you'll mostly spend your time as, appropriately, a BUG. The BUG you occupy can be upgraded via disks, which unlock useful abilities like the shotgun, teleportation, flight, the capacity to remotely move large objects, etc. The disk abilities, in turn, can be upgraded by WORMs, which (in true imsim style) are cleverly scattered around the levels and help incentivize exploration and planning.

The primary resource is EGO, which is gathered from user-friendly robots and accessories (like the adorable wee motor, little cameras for selfies, and a bunch of other charming little allies). The secondary resource, which is consumed when using abilities unlocked via disks, is juice - shotgun blasts and flight, for example, expend juice. Taking CTRL of puzzle-relevant hosts like doors, hostile robots, cameras, etc costs EGO and creates a delightful, classically game-y dynamic where balancing your juice, EGO, and health inform decisions about puzzle approaches and routes. It's really just an excellent, thoughtfully fleshed out mechanic that makes engaging with the environment both critical and rewarding.

A mysterious narrator guides you via terminals, and the dialogue associated with those terminals is clever, useful, and has a surprisingly well-manifested voiceover. Prompted by tips from the good Doctor Everyman, the player-as-a-disembodied-ego needs to take CTRL of their environment and unravel the mysterious circumstances aboard the beautifully rendered retro-aesthetic space station where the game is set. I'd like to specifically recognize the clever writing and worldbuilding - Ctrl Alt Ego manages to strike a fine narrative balance between humorous and sinister implications that left me hungry for more exposition and delighted whenever I found it.

I'd just like to articulate an example of a puzzle that I thought stumped me. I had to open a special door that I couldn't possess. I had scoured all of the adjacent rooms for clues and come up empty. I knew where I had to go and why, but couldn't quite figure out what the solution was. After trying a bunch of things - possessing every camera, maneuvering a little PUP robot (which barks!) to just the right spot, swapping through my various powers, etc, with no success. Finally, in a fit of pique, I picked up an explosive barrel and chucked it right at the offending door - and the blast revealed a special lock that had been stacked underneath some crates I couldn't move manually. Ctrl Alt Ego is essentially a series of "voila!" moments like that and it makes for immensely satisfying moment-to-moment gameplay.

I could go on and on - the cleverness of the descriptions associated with various hosts, the spectacularly free-form puzzles and sense of accomplishment associated with progression, the on-the-nose-but-somehow-not-derivative retrofuturistic style, the clean and legible graphics, etc, but I'll close with this: Ctrl Alt Ego is an exemplar of the imsim genre. It's characterized by the sort of accelerating complexity of puzzles matched by the player's capacity to engage with them, the necessity of careful observation and interaction with the game world, and substantial, genuinely creative exposition and worldbuilding that makes these games so distinct. It hits the perfect medium between contemporary tutorializing, with all it's overexplaining and unnecessary waypoints, and old-school inscrutability. The UI is slick and intuitive, though not particularly fancy.

It has a few, barely perceptible rough edges - I've only had to load a save due to a glitch once, and the only real persistent issue is it can sometimes be hard to select the right host in EGO mode (but there are filters that facilitate that). There are tons of difficulty options, both direct (easy-hard selection) and indirect (tool-tips, waypoints, etc can be toggled), the former of which has a major effect on resource accessibility and the likelihood a player who isn't good at puzzles (like me) will be frustrated. I'd also like to give a shout-out to the dev for being so responsive to feedback - the wobbly robots caused some motion sickness for other players and they immediately added a stabilization option that removes it, which I actually found helpful myself from time to time.

In summary, this game is a rare, singular work of artistic vision that understands the importance of both narrative and mechanical substance. It feels like something a dedicated team with a unique vision spent years building. I don't usually bother writing reviews, but this game deserves it. Buy it at full price. Buy it twice! If you like Deus Ex, Dishonored, and thoughtful science fiction that asks genuine questions about selfhood, identity, and time, you'll find this game is a lot more than the sum of it's parts. 10/10.
 
Dong Quixote

Évaluation publiée le 21 novembre 2022
このゲームは高品質なイマーシブシム(没入シミュレーション)FPSである。
イマーシブシムってなんだよという人が多いと思うため解説すると、ストーリーベースのゲームで一つの問題点に対して固まった解法が用意されておらず、好きな方法で進めてもよいという設計のゲーム全般を指す模様。
比較的最近のゲームでわかりやすく言うならPreyやDishonored、Hitmanなど。Gloomwoodなんかもこれに当たる。
なのにSteamで没入シミュレーションのタグを調べると〇〇シミュレータやスポーツゲーが死ぬほど引っ掛かる。つまり誰も理解していないのである。悲しいね
全体的なボリュームとしてはじっくり探索して16時間のため、サクサク進めれば12時間程度か。

ざっくりとしたゲームシステム紹介
自分も自分以外も全員ロボのFPS。
プレイヤーはロボやインターフェースのCtrlシステムをハッキングすることで乗っ取り、乗り移って進んでいくことになる。
基本的にロボットやインターフェース内に入って行動していくことになるのだが、プレイヤー本体はあくまで「エゴ(自我)そのもの」であるため、動かしていたロボットが消し飛んだとしてもそのまま他のロボを乗っ取ればいいだけであり、それを利用して進む場面もある。
イマーシブシムだけあって進行に対する解法が多く、ステルスしてもいいし全部破壊して安全に進んでもいいし全部ハックして制御下においてもいいし抜け道を通ってギミック全無視してもいい。
サポートしてくれるDr.エブリマンさんのサポートも優しいため、指示通りに動いてもするすると進める。

主人公の強化要素
プレイヤーが基本的に操作する「Bug」ユニットはアップグレード.exeの入ったフロッピーディスクやアップグレードワーム(本当に虫)によりプログラムの習得・強化を行うことが出来、プログラムはエーテルエネルギーを消費して使うことが出来る。
エーテルエネルギーはそこらに落ちているオイルのほか、ジュースを飲むことでも回復が可能。エーテルジュースマズそう
プログラムはエーテルエネルギーを圧縮してブチ撒けるショットガン、物質を動かすシフト、物質を反物質に変換するフォルトなど大量に用意されており、探索・攻略を助ける。
プログラムは取得順が特に決められておらず、持っているアップグレード.exe1枚につき好きなプログラムを覚えることが可能。
しかし実はほとんどのプログラムは無くても攻略が出来るようになっており、何なら「ジャンプ」のモジュールすら任意取得である。
最初の一個目のプログラム以外一切取らずにクリアの実績などもある。

妙にリアルな挙動
ロボはホバー移動やキャタピラ移動、ローラー4点移動など移動手段やカメラ位置が異なり、
よりによって挙動がクソ真面目に適用されるため、ホバーの場合はすごい傾くし滑る。
本体が回転するとカメラもすごい回る。
監視カメラは当然FOVが跳ね上がって魚眼レンズになる。
多分酔う人はものすごく酔う。

難易度
FPS的な難易度は高くなく、無限復活かつ現在状況はそのまま残るため、下手でもそのうちクリア可能。
どちらかというと宇宙ステーションの探索・攻略に重きを置いている感じ。

まとめ
レトロフューチャーな見た目でしっかりとSFしていてイマーシブシムをやりたいなら大当たり。
日本語訳はなく文章がかなり多いためある程度翻訳機を噛ますか英語が読める人向け。

Évaluation publiée le 28 mai 2023
Ctrl Alt Ego has treated me to one of the most open-ended experiences I've ever had among any immersive sim I've played. It's criminal how relatively unknown this game is and I strongly recommend it if you are a fan of the genre.

I've played and enjoyed the recent Deus Ex games, Dishonored, and Prey (2017) and when I started playing Ctrl Alt Ego, and I was absolutely floored with the amount of different ways I could approach a problem. The sheer amount of solutions to a problem can be credited to the mechanic that sets Ctrl Alt Ego apart from other im-sim's; you can posess and take control of various objects in the environment. You can control a wide array of elements in the environment such as BUG's, PUP's, DAD's, MUM's, trip mines, cameras, doors, elevators, etc. each with their own unique set of functions and limitations. These objects are relatively simple to understand on their own but when you start to use them to play off of one another, you will begin to realize there are nearly limitless ways to approach a problem. This open-ended gameplay lends itself really well to multiple playthroughs.

I think this game is better geared for instrically motivated players over extrinsically motivated players. The narrative isn't as engaging as the imm-sim games I mentioned earlier. I think this could be improved with a stronger narrative hook in the beginning portion of the game. If you are reading the computer logs/META pages of certain objects you control in the early levels, you can get the sense something weird happened on the space station and this is really cool but I kind of wish there was more beyond some environmental hints.


I also want to give credit to MindThunk for being a really active developer. I purchased the game months after it was launched and it was still getting bug fixes, new features, and just a few days ago a new content update with the sandbox mode. I also think it's very nice how active he is on various forums answering any questions players have or trying to learn more about technical issues they encounter.

Truly awesome immersive sim. A bit like an Arkane style im-sim in that it gives the player a list of really unique superpowers and asks them to use them in an internally consistent world. The biggest break from Arkane’s formula is that CTRL ALT EGO leans more towards puzzle solving than action, although plenty of the latter is possible. I have some criticisms, but they are all nitpicks that aren’t worth bringing up in a review.

Steam Deck users: this game works perfectly out of the box without even needing to find a community control scheme. The battery drains a little faster than in other similar games, but at least a couple hours are possible on a full charge.

Évaluation publiée le 3 février 2023
I first heard about Ctrl Alt Ego on a Reddit post in mid-2022 the week the game launched. It seemed like an interesting game and I’m a huge immersive sim fan, so I bought it out of principle to support the indie developer for making such a niche and very difficult to develop style of game. Fast forward a few months, and I started hearing rumblings in the immersive sim community about how great the game was. This week, I finally sat down to play it and I was extremely impressed.

In Ctrl Alt Ego, you play as a disembodied consciousness that is able to jump between various electronic objects, like robots, cameras, etc., and possess them. You mostly spend your time in a robot known as Bug 22, who serves as your primary vessel and is the bot you will acquire upgrades for throughout the game. Upgrades include a shotgun, a vacuum, the ability to download items and spawn them in front of you, and much more. When your vessel is destroyed, you just choose something else to jump to. Bug 22 can also be reprinted as much as you need when it is destroyed, so there isn’t a true fail state in the game. Like any good immersive sim, there are a wide variety of playstyles and ways to progress, and a bit of creative thinking potentially leads to some “I can’t believe that worked” moments. You can be stealthy or run and gun. You can hack everything and turn bots against each other or conserve your Ego resource and find another way through environmental manipulation or something else. Don’t have a tool needed for one solution? You could most likely use another to make another way forward. The game combines the level design of imsims like Prey and System Shock with the tool heavy experimentation of Thief while putting a strong emphasis on the puzzle solving element of the genre. I HATE most puzzles in games but the key difference here is that the open nature of Ctrl Alt Ego allowed me to think of my own solutions instead of frantically search for THE solution. Throw in a refreshing, somewhat lighter-hearted tone and aesthetic (at least on the surface) and you have one of the most unique immersive sims I’ve ever played.

I also want to touch on the HUD options. The game allows for optional hints and objective markers that can be turned on and off at your leisure. This is fantastic and it’s something we need to see in more games. I hate quest marker discourse but my take is that there is nothing wrong with objective markers themselves (some people need them due to disabilities or just a horrid sense of direction), but having them in games can make level design lazier since there isn’t a need for the player to learn layouts by analyzing the environment around them, so you end up with locations that feel very “video gamey” and don’t make much practical sense. Therefore, I am of the opinion that games should be designed without markers in mind, but include them as an option for those who want them. That is exactly what this game does. I played the majority of the game with them off, but there were a few moments where I was stumped as to the location of the next objective, so I went into the options menu and briefly turned them on to see where I needed to go, then turned them off again. This option enabled me to have an immersive experience where I searched the environment extensively with an out in case I searched everywhere and was hardstuck. There are going to be moments in games where a developer screws up and doesn’t include any easily decipherable hints as to where to go for a specific objective or even messes up the directions given to you (looking at you, Morrowind). This addition ensures that the player will be able to progress no matter what should worst come to worst. It’s especially great these are here since the game is so niche that there aren’t any written walkthroughs for it that I have seen.

As great as the game is, it has a few problems. It’s a Unity game and comes with very wonky Unity physics that make navigation with some of the bots in some areas very difficult. Notably, using the PUP on some surfaces can make it turn in ways it shouldn’t and you could potentially fall off an elevated location. Furthermore, moving MUMs between surfaces is sometimes near impossible and creates an issue where they can’t move forward when they should be able to. The Unity engine also causes some severe performance dips later in the game, particularly in areas that have a lot of enemies or have mirrors. The combat in the game is very basic and feels extremely clunky, partially because of the robotic nature of the characters but still. There is also an insane difficulty spike during a later part of the game where there is an area with around 20 roving enemy bots that will swarm you if you aren’t careful. They can fly too, so they can seemingly come out of nowhere when your back is turned and kill you in seconds. Lastly, and I could be wrong about this, but I suspect that this game has a few instances where soft locks are possible. During the aforementioned difficulty spike, there was a point where two enemy bots were literally spawn camping me as they stood next to the only bot printer I had available at that time, resulting in one of the few instances of me reloading a save. I also think I found a problem with the last puzzle of the game where I was nearly locked out of completing it because a controllable enemy wandered to me past a gate that wouldn’t open after it shut behind the enemy. I was at an absolute loss as to how I could possibly figure it out (this was getting the DEV disk for those of you who played). Thankfully, I used a very specific upgrade in a very non-conventional manner to complete the puzzle and finish the game. However, this solution was so weird that I feel like there either had to be another way or I was locked out of the normal solutions.

Being an immersive sim fan isn’t always easy. Due to how hard they are to design and the fact that most of them don’t sell well, Triple A immersive sims aren’t very common. These days, most big-budget imsims are either made by Arkane (such as Prey, Dishonored, and Deathloop), or they’re totally cursed and stuck in development hell (like Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines 2, System Shock 3, or whatever was supposed to come after Deus Ex: Mankind Divided). Thankfully, the indie scene is picking up the slack and delivering great experiences like the one I’m reviewing here. Ctrl Alt Ego was made by literally two people and is an excellent game that shows the future of this genre is bright, regardless of what happens in the Triple A space.

8.5/10
 
Spitfyr

Évaluation publiée le 30 décembre 2022
This title is an essential entry into the "Immersive Sim" genre (Prey + Mooncrash, System Shock, Deus Ex, Dishonored, Thief). There's a generously long demo which gives a far better impression than any review will.

As for other games in the genre, there is a lot of player freedom in how to tackle each obstacle. Where this game distinguishes itself is its core mechanic: the player is disembodied and has the ability to hijack and control most other robots for a small resource cost. This means that enemies aren't just obstacles, but tools that can be used to solve the level.

This mechanic alone makes the game worth checking out but on top of it there's also
  • Novel player abilities - standout ability was Fault that allows for turning any physics object into a bomb then infecting other nearby objects with the bomb state for huge chain reactions
  • Levels that get larger and more non-linear as the game progresses
  • Great enemy design - There's only a small handful of enemy types but each type has distinct behaviour and the level design + player options prevents this from getting stale

In short, 10/10, just try the demo.

Other notes:
  • Performance was decent, just above recommended specs and kept the game locked to 60 fps as 120 wasn't attainable, some frame drops when causing massive chain reactions with explosives)
  • There's no inventory management

I'm biased as hell, because I've translated the game, but I've became a fan long before working on it.

This is the one and only immersive sim that is close to Deus Ex 2000 in freedom, expressiveness and design. At every moment you're the most powerful being in the room and also you're in the worst position possible and everyone wants you dead.

It is also one of the best puzzle games out there. The story is interesting, deep and funny at the same time. Level design is superb, sound is crunchy and the graphics are... stylish...

There's lots and lots of accessibility options so if something's bugging you, you can change it!
There's also a pack of hard missions for true immersive sim'ers..? And also, there's a sanbox mode where you can randomly generate, share and play infinite amounts of new levels!

True modern classic and my favourite game alongside DE!

Évaluation publiée le 1 janvier
《Ctrl Alt Ego》=《Prey》+《Watch Dogs》+《Ghost Trick》+《程序员笑话集》
Prey：简直不像小独立团队能做出来的高度凝练的关卡地图结构和多途径完成目标的能力系统，每关都可以无击杀无警觉零资源开的超灵活底层系统。
Watch Dogs：骇入一切的能力，略带潜行的玩法，资源控制的规划，以及以掌握视野和路线规划为核心的破关思路。
Ghost Trick：“万物皆我”的操控逻辑与“我为何物”的哲学思考，需要理解并利用被控制物件特性的操作模式，带有很强解谜性质的关卡推进模式。同时与《幽灵诡计》不同，物件特性逻辑更加系统完备化，避免了对电波的解谜思考。
程序员笑话集：从最初的机制教学导入到后面的分支收集lore，甚至是最基础的系统名称，到处都充斥着诙谐幽默的程序员段子，虽然目前没有中文，且部分谐音和双关梗应该很难翻译成中文，但光是就我能看懂的部分来说可以算是有相当高级的幽默感了，时刻能让我会心一笑。

当然，CAE可不止只有从前辈中学习的优点。CAE是我玩过的唯一“不过度强调减员”的沉浸式模拟游戏，虽然别的游戏也有“想怎么玩就这么玩，杀敌击晕潜行绕过或更有创造力的方式都能通关”的口号，但最终的结果往往是如果不用道德值、混乱度、评分系统等外部手段加以限制，击杀击晕或者说减员永远是最直观的选项，玩家直觉上并不会把它和其他手段摆在同等地位。而CAE优秀的底层系统设计和叙事结构逻辑能让你真正感受到，游戏里并没有真正的敌人甚至没有真正的死亡，所有东西都是关卡的一部分，所谓的敌人威胁不过是攻克关卡这栋大厦中的一块砖，也许这块砖有砸到自己的风险，但粉碎它只是手段中的一种，合理规避甚至利用它也可以让这些砖块为自己铺出一条前进的道路。
CAE真可谓是青出于蓝而胜于蓝，学习百家之所长而做出了自己的风采。虽然由于小团队规模制作导致中后期的新内容新机制偏少，破关手法可能会有一定的定势和通解导致略带一定重复度，但是把自己的想法实现到如此高的完成度，而且甚至没有以Early Access形式而是推出完demo以后直接出了正式版，其强大的项目管理能力实在令人汗颜（《Gloomwood》、《Fortune's Run》、《Fallen Aces》你们说是吧……），可谓是沉浸式模拟在独立游戏领域的一大里程碑了。
 
GrionNutritious

Évaluation publiée le 24 décembre 2022
尽管在商业上可能表现不佳，但并不妨碍本作成为Immersive Sim的史上佳作之一。

什么叫酒香也怕巷子深啊，这就是活脱脱的例子。要不是油管up Charlatan Wonder我根本不会知道有这么个游戏，然后我一点进商店页面就差点被画质给劝退了：这啥啊？

不过这几年科幻Immersive Sim要么还处于种小麦的阶段，要么直接难产，实在游戏荒的我还是决定试试本作。但是一上手，我就被本作极高的完成度震惊了，这真是俩人（其中一个还中途跑路了）做出来的游戏？

解谜和关卡推进、剧情发展完美而自然地融合在一起，毫无割裂感。制作人没有限制玩家以任何方式推进关卡，游戏也没有道德值一类的指标对玩家进行“道德评判”，无论你是喜欢杀光眼前一切敌人的FPS玩家还是喜欢追求潜行和0杀的和平主义者都能找到适合自己的风格，甚至即便玩家不是剧情党，不看文档也能一样享受游戏。复杂（但不会导致迷路，因为游戏有相当友好的路牌指示）而有新意的关卡设计在为多种过关方式提供底层支撑的同时能让玩家直到通关都会不断产生探索的新鲜感。“场景重复度高”“关卡设计单一”这样的评价绝对和本作无缘。引导恰到好处，既不会让玩家产生“我是谁我要干啥”的想法，也不会让玩家产生“你在教我做事？”的恼火。在Immersive Sim的设计哲学上，这款游戏无疑是做得相当好的。

然后是一点私货，这个游戏真的有好多码农看了会心一笑的梗哈哈哈，作者一看就是资深码农了，比如Merging Station那个版本管理，日常被git整到头疼的我很难不共情~

这个游戏除了画面外似乎很难找到什么令人恼火的短板，但奇怪的是在国外都不怎么火，国内由于本地化问题就更别说了。可能是Immersive Sim本身就小众，加上steam商店里挂的截图画质实在有点劝退，再加上制作人没钱搞宣发导致了这样的结果。这样的精品独立游戏被埋没还是很可惜的，好评支持一下吧。

全收集强迫症请进。 If you want to find all worms, disks and memory cards in CAE, this guide is for you.

Évaluation publiée le 26 septembre 2022
Yarış oyunlarının bende yeri çok ayrıdır. Arabalara, yarışlara ilgim çok küçük yaşta daha yürümeyi bile öğrenmeden başladı. Oyuncak arabalar, sadece resimlerine baktığım araba dergileri derken kendimi çok küçük yaşta bir bilgisayarın başında Need for Speed oynarken buluverdim. Yıllar boyunca dijital dünyada direksiyon salladım, yıllarca yarıştım birinci geldim ki zaten bir yarış oyununu kazanmanın yoluda buydu, birinci gelmek. Ancak yıllar sonra Driver San Francisco isimli bir yarış oyunu ile karşılaştım. Bu Driver serisi ile ilk karşılaşmam değildi ve aşağı yukarı ne ile karşılaşacağımıda biliyordum. Bu sefer San Francisco şehrinde gerçek araba markalarıyla bir araba yarışı oynayacaktım, ne güzel. Oyuna başladım, ilk görevi bitirdim ve oyun bana daha önce hiç görmediğim bir mekanik tanıttı "Shift" mekaniği.

Bu mekanik ne diyenler için anlatayım. Shift mekaniği oyuncuyu sürücü koltuğundan alıp oyun alanına kuş bakışı bir kamera ile baktırıp oyuncunun imleç ile üzerine geldiği arabanın kontrolünü oyuncuya veren diğer bir değişle oyun alanındaki her arabayı kontrol edebilmemizi sağlayan bir mekanik. Yıllarca dijital dünyada direksiyon salladım ve bunun sonucunda tek bir şey öğrenmiştim o da yarışı kazanmak için birinci gelmemiz gerektiğiydi ancak Driver San Francisco bu Shift mekaniği ile kendi arabamızı 1 metre bile sürmeden yarışı kazanabilme imkanı sunuyordu. Yarışta arabamızdan Shift ile çıkıp kamyona geçip diğer yarışçıların arabalarını parçalayabilir, polis arabası alıp diğer yarışçılara çarpıp peşlerine polisi takabilir ya da yarış dışında polise çarptıysak ve uğraşmak istemiyorsak başka bir arabaya geçip oyunumuza rahatça devam edebilirdik yani yıllarca yarış oyunu oynamış birinin bile ilk kez bir yarış oyunu oynuyormuşçasına keyif almasını sağladı. Oyun Shift mekaniğinin gücünün farkında olup her bir anında onu daha eğlenceli daha etkili kullanmayı amaçladığı için çok eğlenceli ve özgün bir yarış oyunu olmuştu.Bu mekaniğin robot hacklemek veya bir süreliğine başka bir bedenin kotrolünü elimize almak gibi türevleri olsada oyunun bütününü bu mekanik üzerine kuran başka bir oyun çıkmamıştı.

İşte tamda burada Ctrl Alt Ego devreye giriyor. Sadece araba sürebildiğimiz bir oyunda bile oynanışı bu kadar çeşitlendiren bu mekanik bir Immersive Sim'de yani tamamiyle oyuncunun bir sorunu çözmesi üzerine kurulu bir oyunda nasıl mı olmuş? Tek kelime ile HARİKA. Yeterli Ego puanınız olduğu sürece oyun alanındaki her şeyin (düşman, kamera, tablet...) kontrolünü elimize alabiliyoruz. Yeri gelir karşındaki her şeyi eritip başka bir yerde spawn edebilen bir düşmanın kontrolünü, yeri gelir daracık yerlere girebilen bir robotun kontrolünü elimize alabilmek yetmezmiş gibi bir çokta karakter geliştirmeside bu mekanikle birleşince problem çözmek acayip eğlenceli olmuş.

Son dönemlerde tekrardan popülerleşen Immersive Sim türünün bir sorunu şu ki sadece eskiden çıkmış Immersive Sim oyunlarını tekrardan yapıyormuş gibi hissettirmesi. Türün şu "kutuları üst üste koyup bölümü geçme" olayı yeni birçok Immersive Sim'i bir lanet gibi sarmış türe yenilik katmaktansa, gücü oyuncuya vermektense sadece bir oyuncunun çözebileceği tarzda çözümleri problemin çözümü yapmak sanan birtakım oyunlar yüzünden tür son zamanlarda her ne kadar geri dönüş yapmış olsada eskisi gibi ilgi çekici değillerdi. Üzgünüm Gloomwood evet çok güzel Souls vari bölüm tasarımların var, evet save scummingi engellemek için çokta güzel bir yöntem bulmuşsun ve evet bugün artık antika sayılan Thief, Deus Ex gibi oyunların yerine her zaman seni önereceğim ama bana seni oynamam için "yeni" bir sebep vermiyorsun. Ama Ctrl Alt Ego ise türde yeni hissettiren bu mekaniği ile çokta fazla oyuncağa sahip olması ve tabii ki de oyununda bunları anlayıp mantıklı cevaplar vermesi sayesinde son zamanlarda oynamaktan en keyif aldığım Immersive Sim olmayı başarmıştır. 2 kişilik ufak ekibi buradan tebrik ediyorum. Zaten bir şekilde bu incelemeyi okuyorsanız Immersive Sim türünü duymuşsunuz demektir tamda bu sebeple bu incelemeyi okuyan herkese oyunu öneriyorum.

Évaluation publiée le 25 juin 2023
This is a truly brilliant game. Really original and creative. I think it did extremely well on the following points:

- Well-functioning 3D environment with realistic graphics.
- Simulated danger and "combat" which does not involve the grim and depressing elements of a typical FPS. There is a gun option available (among many others) but you don't have to use it.
- Well executed humor
- Good voice acting
- Enjoyable plot line
- Good amount of playtime
- Great physics-based game mechanics
- Extraordinary flexibility in problem solving, ie difficult strategic challenges with multiple unique solutions.

The only negative, if you can call it that, is that the difficulty level (for me) rose sharply later in the game. I was really daunted at one point, but did get things sorted out after discussion with the devs. Note to devs: Don't change a thing!

This is a hidden gem that unfortunately may not get the exposure it deserves. It is very very well done.

* Unique and fun gameplay mechanics, check.
* Interesting, well written, and well voice acted story, check.
* Open ended immersive gameplay systems that let you complete your goals in a variety of ways, with a variety of tools, check.
* Great save system with lot's of opportunity to mess around with fairly little punishment but still manages to give you the motivation to not die, check.
* Overall the game design is top notch.
* Decent graphics, check.
* Fair price, check.

Considering the depth and complexity of the systems that the game has in it I am also happy to report that I have ran into very very few bugs, and no game breaking bugs. I had one crash but it was after leaving my computer on the pause screen for about 40 minutes while eating dinner. Game seems very stable overall when playing.

There is so much to love about this game, and I can't recommend it enough to people who like immersive sims like Prey, Dishonored, etc. For the price this a must play. We just don't get enough games like this and I'm very happy to have found this game.

Just a quick early review to say that this is a fun puzzler. My method here is to do about an hour or two and then do a new game immediately. It takes a little bit of time to absorb all the mechanics of the game and a replay just really makes things come into focus. The developer is on hand if you run into a problem but I have had no bugs or glitches and everything seems to be running smoothly.


Edit: Yes, buy a copy for yourself and a friend. I'm over 50 hours in now and still not quite sure how this is going to end. What a great game with unlimited saves and reloads. Lots of achievements to uncover and a few challenging ones thrown in too. There's a lot to understand at first glance but that quickly fades as you gain more experience. Excellent environments to explore and with a very generous difficulty scale you'll have no problem getting around. Great voice acting to keep you amused but not overly chatty or distracting. A good HUD with tabs to keep you informed and a full option menu to customize your gameplay.

A real gem, one of my best buys for the year.

These two absolutely smashed it out of the park. If you liked Prey 2017 then you will absolutely adore this title. A very well deserved 9.5 out of 10. Would be higher were it not for some frame rate issues in the last levels.
