Évaluation publiée le 27 novembre 2022
A top tier Immersive Simulated Experience. If you're even aware of this genre then you're likely to find a decent bit of enjoyment in this game. It takes the light puzzle element present in many imsims and brings it to the forefront of the experience, to the point where it's more dominant than the usual first person shooter framing, you don't even need to get a gun. This makes for a really unique experience, especially thanks to just how open for creativity the game is clearly built.

There are so many great mechanics on display here that i don't know where to start and where would i even end with them. Not only is there an already solid foundation of abilities your bug is able to do, which range from a typical shotgun to being able to spawn most objects and enemies in the game, but there is also the ability to take control of almost any significant enemy or object that might be standing in your way (this is also why that latter ability is actually pretty significant). This opens up so many options. You may use them as scouts, as safer passages into the next area, to smuggle things into the enemy circles or to just attack the enemies outright while keeping your bug safe and the list goes on... I will not mention everything not only because it would go on for way too long but also because the fun part is figuring out how to best use all these mechanics to get past some often pretty tough challenges. Creativity can often really pay off! There have been a fair few moments where after figuring out a fun solution to a problem i had been stuck on for a while i laughed, thinking "I can't believe that actually worked!"

Ctrl alt ego has a particular retro futuristic aesthetic of huge and bulky machines in a world set in the far far future that is fairly distinct, in a way it's interesting to see a game focus on an aesthetic from the past that is not so flashy. Its visuals may not be the strongest aspect, but i don't think they can really be called a flaw. Plus i do actually really like all the robot designs. The game also has quite a bit of humor in it and it generally delivers with some fun writing while in possesion of hosts. One of my favorites of these is the song that plays while in possesion of a DOR (which alone makes me wish for some kind of ost release). The story follows in similar footsteps, with a bunch of absurd humor and while it is at times confusing and takes a while to get going i still found it interesting and very fitting for the game. All this combined with quirks like the many cat pictures or worms as upgrades(ready to worm is a great phrase), the game does have a charm to it.

Overall, Ctrl Alt Ego really is a wonderful game. It stands toe to toe with many acclaimed games in the genre and i think it even surpasses many of them in its gameplay. I can't say there's a whole lot i dislike about it either, other than some pretty minor nitpicks. I'm likely going to be replaying it and messing around more with some of its mechanics i havent gotten to use as much and trying some of its harder challenges.

Évaluation publiée le 20 aout 2022
Ctrl Alt Ego is a joy of a game I did not expect.

I played the classic Looking Glass (Ultima Underworld, System Shock, Thief) and Arkane (Arx Fatalis, Dark Messiah, Dishonored, Prey) games as they were released, and I'm always looking for games whose developers show a similar love for smart and enjoyable worldbuilding. Those don't come along every day, so to discover a new game that not only "gets" the immersive sim vibe but manages to add its own fresh take on the genre is an absolute delight.

Ctrl Alt Ego is the rare game that coherently integrates its mechanics of play with its setting and storytelling with its world-dynamics, each deepening the others with unexpected but perfectly sensible resonances. As you travel through the world, swapping one robot body for another, the question "What am I?" is both part of the the game story and a question to the player, giving real depth to the gameplay fun. Without ever lecturing -- there's some bit of wicked British humor tucked away everywhere -- after briefly pondering the nature of individual consciousness it's easy to realize one moment that you're intently focused on figuring out one of the game's many clever puzzles, then the next moment madly steering your current robotic host around a corner to hide from an alerted antagonist and plan your next move.

This is exactly what a computer game ought to be: smart, distinctive, polished, challenging, funny, thoughtful, and ultimately highly satisfying for someone who enjoys discovering the secrets of a well-designed and fun simulated world. Highly recommended!

Évaluation publiée le 12 juin 2023
Начнём с того, что это НЕ плохая игра, пожалуй даже хорошая. Но сложив все её плюсы и минусы я просто не могу с чистым сердцем её рекомендовать. Если было бы можно, тут стояла честная “смешанная” оценка, а так вынужден поставить отрицательную.

Собственно, минусы:
1) Это игра на юнити, В ПЛОХОМ СМЫСЛЕ.
Прямо что-то на уровне первой поделки про Слендермена (если помните). Графика - страшная, простенькая, одним словом устаревшая лет на 15.
Физика тоже себе на уме. По началу весело от того какая она не предсказуемая, но веселье заканчивается после того, как ваш персонаж отправляется в свободное плавание и благополучно об что-нибудь взрывается пока вы заняты другими делами (было раза 3 как минимум со мной).
При этом производительность - никакущая. Я со своей ноутбучной 3070ти сидел в районе 60-90 фпс (настроек графики, кстати, тоже почти нет).

2)Неравномерная подача сюжета.
Первые 7 часов гемплея сюжета нет практически (а это пол игры). И потом уже начинают появляться персонажи, объясняется что происходит и так далее.
Устройство мира подробно объясняется аж на самой последней локации. А что происходит в концовке я вообще плохо понимаю.

3) Здесь есть оригинальная механика ЭГО, которая представляет собой что-то вроде внутриигровой валюты. В первой половине игры его количество строго ограничено, что заставляет напрячь мозги в зависимости от выбранного варианты прохождения. Но вот во вторую часть игры авторы как будто забивают на всю механику и дают просто практически неограниченные запасы это самого ЭГО. Что, естественно, портит всю экономику игры.(Хотя, пожалуй, если вы проходите игру на пацифизме, то количество оправдано, не проверял.)

4) Тут очень сложно завалить прохождение локации. Смерти ничего не значат, можно печатать персонажа неограниченное количество раз. И даже когда вам кажется, что все пути завалены или недоступны всегда находится ещё один альтернативный. Опять-таки, можно похвалить разработчиков за такую изобретательность. Но с другой стороны это убивает смысл проходить игру каким-то особым образом, прохождение никак не влияет на концовку или сюжет(насколько могу судить). Если и мучатся, то только ради ачивок.

Теперь про хорошее. Тут очень оригинальные и необычные механики геймплея которые вы нигде больше не встретите и которые стоят внимания. Я бы сказал они тянут всю игру. Именно благодаря им у игры рейтинг 96%.

......но в качестве первого вхождения в жанр эмерсив сим точно не советую. Лучше поиграйте в ремейк систем шока. Но если на него нет денег(не продают в СНГ), то и это по скидке зайдёт в целом нормально.

Évaluation publiée le 15 octobre 2022
This is an excellent immersive sim, which I could not put down until I'd reached the credits. It excels at giving the player enormous freedom, and has a very intriguing story to go along with it. It is lean in its systems where it needs to be; there's no inventory management, there's infinite respawning, etc. But it knows where to be complex, where to let the player creatively problem solve and feel like they are coming up with unique solutions. The game knows what is important, and this value-set is what keeps the game fun and engaging from start to finish.

I have a few small nitpicks, but they are very small considering I could not put the game down until the credits rolled. For one, the performance suffers in certain areas even though this game is not a looker, which I put down to poor optimization. Sometimes the audio is not mixed well, and you have some sound effects playing out incredibly loud (explosions, gun shots, certain demonic voices) which can be jarring. My final nitpick is that the physics are super wonky, and sometimes lead to undesirable outcomes like things exploding when you don't want them to, being unable to pick up an item that is inches away, trouble getting your character through doorways and vents, etc.

Overall, an incredibly fun and interesting game from Mindthunk. I might just start a new playthrough now and do things totally differently...

Produit reçu gratuitement

Nauseating and frustrating.

Almost every action requires a warped visual sequence that contribute to a bizarre type of motion sickness. You can also only control either static objects or physics objects, so your vision and movement are subject to forces that feel arbitrary.

Enemies take the form of turrets with undodgeable, nearly unblockable attacks. Fighting them is a chore and sneaking by them is also a pain without the right build.

A weird amount of the dialogue is so self-referential it shatters the suspension of disbelief. They actually say *out loud* that the situation has been contrived for you to succeed at one point.

It's a cool idea that isn't executed horribly, but there are too many consistent issues for it to be a fun time to me.

Can't recommend this game enough so far. As someone with a budding interest over the past year or so in ImmSim type games, and as an average Ghost Trick: Phantom Detective enjoyer, this is just the perfect culmination of mechanics. This is probably the first game to call itself an ImmSim where I really felt like I had many options but no singular dominate strategy. Many choices are viable and let you play around with the very well constructed maps and tools. During my first playthrough I'm not ever feeling boxed into one playstyle or the other, I simply adapt what I do based on what's practical or fun. There's no "full stealth" or "full murder" type of story or resource incentive. It's just you and a large map to solve at your own pace. Helps that the brief amount of story that's hear is quick, snappy, to the point, and interesting, on top of some fun visuals and a handful of oddly catchy tracks.

Truly one of if not THE greatest ImmSim I've ever played, and I ain't even finished it yet. Should something happen that just ruins the game I'll update this, but otherwise assume what I've said here remains true for the whole game, just had to get my feelings out on this one, not NEARLY enough reviews here.

Ctrl Alt Ego is a wildly dynamic and creative immersive sim that absolutely nails what the genre does best. Every situation the game places you in can be solved with wild brute force, avoided entirely with clever stealth, or any manner of interesting idea you can come up with in between using the tools provided.

Évaluation publiée le 2 octobre 2022
I feel bad for not leaving a review for this, I think it deserves a shot.
First of all, there's a demo, steam://install/1820820, it's under the "Is this game relevant to you?" section on the right-hand side of the Steam store page, above the info box going over that it's a singleplayer game with steam achievements, full controller support, captions, cloud etc.
Even if the style might not seem like your thing, just give the demo a go, the save from the demo will be compatible with the full game so you can easily continue if you do like it.

I know it's done to death comparing games with other games ("It's like Skyrim with guns" "Souls-like") but, not sure how to make a quick snappy sales pitch without something that can grab peoples attention.
There's something very british about this (no not just the voice actor), I have flashbacks to Douglas Adams and his funny writings about depressed robots and sighing doors, maybe the retro vibe also, like I vaguely remember seeing an old TV series of Hitchhikers guide to the Galaxy and I feel like this almost fits. Also, picture if Portal and Typhon/Prey 2017 had a weird retro baby, because this is a light-hearted puzzle game with sentient fickle robots, but you have a lot more freedom than a Portal puzzle chamber ever gave you.
You can get a shotgun and solve all your problems that way if you want, or get thrusters and literally fly and rocket into things, or telekinesis arms to lift up heavy objects, or turn other objects into bombs, or "download" and rematerialize new copies of other things, you'll be jumping around everything, almost everything is done in-game, saving is a station you control to go save at, doors you jump to, security systems-- There's so much, and the game has a very encouraging relaxed sense of just trying to assure you at all times that you're not doing anything wrong, even "dying", just experiment, explore, look around, figure things out how you want.
And there's a story, seems neat, I haven't played it a ton yet, not sure how long this game is, but it's pretty fun and engaging and cute.
You do have to be in a puzzly mood, so that's why I haven't played it through yet.

Stop looking at the screenshots, they undersell what an inventive immersive-sim-puzzle game this is, if you like being creative and like any of the stuff I mentioned above (Portal, Prey, Douglas Adams) then I mean at least give the demo a shot, okay, what can you lose?

...I mean... When does the ''Immersive Sim'' part come in?
Ctrl Alt Ego is one of those game that I found out when searching for a new ''Immersive Sim'' to fall in love with, and although the game is actually really good... This feels like a really complex puzzle game more than anything else.
Don't get me wrong: the game offers multiple ways to solve a particular problem (…although, usually, ONE solution is way better than the others), and it does have player freedom in its mindset... but again, the entire premises of the game falls flat when (especially in higher difficulties) the options are not that ''equally'' effective ( I mean, I get it. It's not a RPG... but every single time you approach a puzzle - yep, that s what they are - the optimal solution is just… one).
Beside that, the game is interesting in its story, design and whatnot, and it's definitely worth checking it out (this is why I'm giving it the thumbs up - it really deserves it), despite its ''junkiness'' in some feature, like player movement, revolting camera, and the overall ''unpolishness'' of some of the mechanics (shooting especially).
So... yes! a thrilling... PUZZLE game, with a sprinkle of Immersive Sim right there.

Évaluation publiée le 11 janvier 2023
A bit rough the edges, but so much fun to play.

The gameplay puts a lot of emphasis on letting you come up with your own solutions to levels, and it's really fantastic at that. It makes the gameplay engaging in a way that few games manage to be. If you enjoy thinking about the best way to solve a problem, exploring environments, trying out ideas, and formulating the perfect plan, you'll love this game.

At several turns, I was surprised that the game was even bigger than I expected. My single playthrough took around 20 hours, but the gameplay offers so much choice that I'm looking forward to doing another playthrough.

The story is good, with a few fun twists, good voice acting and a bit of philosophy about what it means to have an identity.

It's good!

Évaluation publiée le 6 juillet 2023
For the price I was expecting some fairly simplistic and janky im-sim gameplay, I was pleasantly surprised, so pleasant in fact that I almost nutted my pants. This game legitimately punches above its weight and can hang with the likes of Thief II and OG Deux Ex. I am just finishing up my playthrough and will be doing another directly afterwards.

You play as a...thing that can control and jump between various robots and devices in order to bypass security and accomplish various objectives on a space station, though there is a "main" bot you'll be controlling/upgrading/sneaking/shotgunning/accidentally exploding or disintegrating over the course of the game. Levels are large and highly interconnected, with tons of hidden routes and secrets to find. There are a variety of tools you can use to traverse the environment and deal with unfriendly bots, and all of them are viable as long as you explore and replenish your resources. You can sneak your way through the entire game, or install a shotgun and grenades to blast everything in your path, or upgrade your bot's thrusters and drill to disassemble and smash enemies with your robot body, or hack unfriendly bots and make them help with combat or traversal, it's all a matter of finding the pieces on the board and figuring out how you want to manipulate them to accomplish your goals. There is something of a boss fight at one point, and this may be the only im-sim that handled this in a way where you are not shoehorned into one of a few pre-set paths and just get boned if your build doesn't quite fit, you can use basically any of the game systems to beat it including finding ways to completely break and bypass it.

As far as story/writing/world-building goes, there's enough to sink your teeth into, but not as rich and meaty as something like Dishonored or Deus Ex. The tone is much more lighthearted and comedic than most im-sim games, and thankfully it steers well clear of cringy/whacky one-liners with a giant signpost saying "HEY THIS IS THE JOKE PLEASE LAUGH NOW", its mostly just dry and silly background details you'll stumble upon and chuckle, more like the humor in Portal as opposed to something like Borderlands or Saints Row.

Performance-wise I have no complaints, I've had no crashes, no bugs (or none that I've noticed at least), and a stable 60+ framerate at 1440p with a Ryzen 3600 + RXT3070. I do get occasional stuttering or framedrops when a lot of explosions and physics objects are interacting on-screen, but they are infrequent and frankly for a game this systematically complex being developed by an absolutely tiny team, the performance is impressive.

I waited until this game was discounted to buy it, but honestly after playing it I regret waiting, the full-price of $20 is a great deal for the amount of fun you'll have even in a single playthrough.

Évaluation publiée le 26 février 2023
Mon tardis au fond du Prey

Mon immersion à moi

L’immersion peut prendre bien des formes, pour moi c’était avant tout une histoire de trench-coat en cuir noir, sous les vestiges d’une statue de la liberté bafouée.
Il y a encore quelques semaines, je n’aurais pas imaginé pouvoir m’y adonner au sein d’une ambiance science fiction british des années 70/80.

Je suis un joueur, un égo et une conscience désincarnée qui peut prendre le contrôle de nombreuses entités, dans un monde qui semble aux premiers abords être une simulation ou plutôt un programme.
Un petit peu comme dans un Nomad Soul, le voile entre mon moi dans le jeu et mon moi dans la réalité peut parfois sembler bien fin.

Bien qu’étant sous la forme d’une entité immatérielle, je passe mon temps à sauter entre de nombreux éléments tangibles, revêtant différentes formes tel le docteur.
Les réceptacles de ma conscience peuvent aller du simple distributeur de boisson au robot autonome, certaines entités m’offrant de multiples possibilités et aptitudes.

Toutes les intéractions avec le jeu sont basées sur ce principe de saut, saut qui n’est pas une téléportation, je me déplace réellement entre les différents éléments.

Ainsi pour sauvegarder, il me faudra sauter dans un appareil dédié à la sauvegarde de ce programme et véritablement utiliser son écran dans le jeu.
Pour obtenir des informations, je pourrais prendre possession de tablettes tactiles.
Pour communiquer avec mon énigmatique interlocuteur/guide, je prendrais le contrôle de bornes nommées C.A.T. .

A ma disposition, j’ai surtout deux entités qui peuvent se mouvoir. Tout d’abord les Pup, des petits chiens robot qui me permettent de me faufiler un peu partout, d’explorer le terrain furtivement, d’ouvrir des portes et même d’aboyer pour attirer l’attention.
Chaque Pup a son propre petit nom.

Ensuite j’ai les Bugs, des robots qui n’ont pas forcément leur place en ces lieux. Plus particulièrement, j’ai Bug 22. C’est lui mon réceptacle principal, que je peux upgrader pour obtenir de nombreux outils.

Bien évidemment, je ne suis pas le bienvenu, l’environnement n’accepte pas ma présence et divers systèmes de sécurités et entités hostiles sont en place. Si je peux les contrôler et profiter de leurs capacités, cela se fait au prix d’une ressource : l’Ego, au sens propre comme figuré.

L’Ego s’obtient dans, l’environnement, la prise de contrôle de certaines machines, la destruction de mes adversaires, la découverte de secrets.
Je parlais plus haut de double sens, c’est car j’ai compris assez rapidement que gaspiller mon Ego pour trouver une solution implique aussi de perdre une part d’égo de moi même, le joueur. Car en étant malin, en déployant de bonnes tactiques avec tous les outils que j’ai en main, en exécutant avec brio mes plans, en observant et en découvrant, je peux surmonter bien des épreuves sans gaspiller mon Ego dans le jeu.

Deux autres ressources sont utiles, l’Energie des hôtes (et objets) que je vais contrôler, qui est en quelque sorte leur santé et influence leurs mouvements et formes et le Juice de mon Bug 22, qui est utilisé pour alimenter ses capacités.

Si le jeu se déroule en plusieurs chapitres, je peux me balader librement entre les différents niveaux et y revenir quand je le désire si je le souhaite. Il y a des chargements entre les niveaux mais on conserve tout objet que l’on déplace.
Ces niveaux sont souvent liés entre eux de manière cohérente; via une multitude d'embranchements. Ensemble, ils constituent 3 faux mondes ouverts, un peu comme Prey, en restant quand même bien éloigné du génie architectural au budget AAA de Talos.

Le level design est bon, déjà par toutes les possibilités offertes sur les niveaux les plus ouverts (les premiers niveaux sont plus linéaires), la verticalité et les secrets. Mais aussi car je peux débloquer plein de raccourcis et chemins, qui sont utiles au backtracking ou pour passer outre les dangers.
Il y a un chapitre/lieu en particulier qui est une belle claque grâce à son immensité et sa richesse.

Les chapitres rythment une histoire assez meta et cryptique au début, dont je ne vais rien dévoiler ici.

Surabondance d’Inputs et Outputs

A l’instar de divers autres immersive sim, l’observation et l’infiltration sont de la partie. Je passe donc mon temps à déjouer les systèmes de sécurité, tromper les ennemis et analyser le terrain avant de m’avancer.
L’IA est attentive aux mouvements d’objets et bruits qu’ils peuvent émettre dans leur manipulation. Plus on éveille les soupçons d’une entité, plus elle est alerte.
Mais ici il n’est pas question de jouer avec les ombres ou de se pencher, il est nécessaire d’utiliser de la physique (par exemple placer judicieusement des containers qui peuvent obstruer le champ de vision d’un adversaire) et des multiples aptitudes de nos hôtes.
Bien sûr, le fait d’être un système immatériel qui peut sauter entre plusieurs éléments anodins de l’environnement m’aide aussi.

L’immersive sim peut prendre bien des formes, Prey avait celle de l’immersive sim créatif.
Par ce terme je catégorise les titres qui vont m’offrir plein d’outils et me permettre de créer des pièges et solutions innovantes.
Beaucoup parlent d’immersive sim puzzle, si c’est assez juste dans l’idée de résoudre des problématiques, je n’aime pas trop cette dénomination car un puzzle, pour moi, a une connotation de solution unique.
A l’inverse, tout le sel de ces jeux est d’offrir plein de solutions et de laisser le joueur libre de ses tactiques.

Vous l’aurez compris, Ctrl Alt Ego est un immersive sim créatif et même plus que ça, il en est un des plus grands représentants !

Tout d’abord, il est doté d’un moteur physique qui gère la plupart des éléments disponibles dans l’environnement (et même nos hôtes). Je passe ainsi mon temps à jouer avec tout ce qui est disponible dans l’environnement.
A chaque affrontement, à chaque problème, il est question de physique.
Un pack d'énergie trop loin m’oblige à me mettre à découvert ? Je peux, entre autres, l’attirer avec le super aspirateur de Bug 22.
Un accès en hauteur empruntable par un Pup ? Je peux, entre autres, en jeter un dedans
Un piège à bug (mine) sur mon chemin ? Je peux, entre autres, le faire voler à vive allure vers un adversaire avec système d’impulsion de Bug 22.
J’énonce ici des exemples simples, cela devient particulièrement passionnant quand on combine les solutions et effets.

L’autre particularité qui rend le jeu créatif concerne les capacités offertes par les robots et principalement Bug 22. Celles-ci sont assez originales et ouvrent bien des possibilités.
Par exemple, il est possible d’introduire une erreur (fault) dans un objet ou entité, ce qui le rendra explosif au moindre contact en mouvement. J’aime l’appliquer sur un débris de robot, pour ensuite le jeter sur un autre ennemi ou le mettre sur son chemin.

Rarement un jeu m’a autant offert la possibilité de combattre mes adversaires sans utiliser la moindre arme.
D’ailleurs, si Bug 22 peut obtenir une arme à feu, c’est une capacité comme les autres. On est libre de débloquer les capacités de son choix, dans l’ordre que l’on souhaite, et donc de jouer sans aucune arme.

Le bug est dans les détails

La suite est disponible ici : Forum CanardPC[forum.canardpc.com]

Évaluation publiée le 14 novembre 2022
This game is for you if you:
- like immersive sims.
- enjoy being creative in solving problems.
- know basics of software developement/programming.

This game is probably not for you if you:
- need AAA graphics.
- want smooth gameplay and don't like clunkiness. (If you liked Deus Ex: Human Revolution or MD but didn't enjoy the original Deus Ex.)
- like games with lots of dialogues... or any dialogues, for that matter.
- hate cats.

Some positives:
- The game world is consistent and makes sense.
- It is really funny. (I know it's not something I wanted from the game, but it took me quite by surprise how joyful was the experience. Also the jokes are not thrown into your face, which is definitely a plus.)
- The game is longer than it looks like, and in the second half it really opens up.
- It is not only great immersive sim game by itself, but it offers new mechanics and concepts for the whole genre.
- There is a demo with the Prologue and first two levels.

Some negatives:
- The opening is not so good. The Prologue (first level) is quite hard by itself (especially if you want to play stealthily), you are trying to learn the controls, get used to the clunkier elements (since a lot of the game is physics driven)... it is a bit messy. And even if the game tells you that you can skip the level, you don't really want to do that, do you? After that it gets much better, but it still throws at you CATs and GODs and EMUs while you teleport around and try to understand why you can control some things and not the others. It took me a while before everything started making more sense.
- The performance can be not great on less powerful machines. I played the game on Steam Deck and while most of the game was fine at steady 30 FPS, in some situations it dropped quite a bit, mainly in later bigger levels (especially in the last one).
- While the game is very flexible and gives you a lot of options how to solve problems, it also oftens offers you a specific approach for solving it (even in later parts of the game) and I have mixed feelings about that.

Évaluation publiée le 11 octobre 2022
TLDR: Great stuff, definitely worth trying. I bought the game even before finishing free demo, which alone contains more than many full games.

One of the best games I have ever had luck to find by pure accident. Original and unique idea, not simple, not overcomplicated, but definitely satisfying and addictive.

Base premise speaks for itself:
You play as a computer bug (mostly), but you can also be a pup or a door. Or, you can play as something that is usually your enemy. And your enemies are dads, mums, computer viruses, security cams, or other computer bugs chasing after you with disassembler in their hand.

Sounds too weird and bizzare? Well, it's less than you would think.
The world you are in is fairly complex and challenging, but not difficult to navigate and you will soon get used to its specific features. You can even fly around, which is always a sign of good level design. Your actions do not feel repetitive, because you have many options and you can always use variety of different ways to deal with the situation. This naturally provides for good replayability. Generous save system (well, maybe a bit too generous) allows you to casualy play from time to time without being limited by poorly located checkpoints, as well as to try different approaches ad nausea.

I came accross a few glitches, none of them was gamebreaking and some could even be accepted as part of experience. Controls seemed clunky at first, but then I realized it is probably on purpose. Game contains a lot of reading material, usually not necessary unless you want to know the complete story.

And last, but not least, very good technical state. Many features, that some people can find unpleasant, can be adjusted in settings. The game natively supports superwide screen resolution, which is not obvious for many AAA wannabes. And it is created and continuously maintained by devoted developers (two?!) who clearly know what they are doing. That gives me hope for a lot of future DLCs with new levels, missions and maybe new features.

Even if the game was abandoned tomorrow, it is already excellent stuff worth buying.

Évaluation publiée le 15 juillet 2023
This review does not contain any spoilers.

Ctrl Alt Ego is a finely crafted immersive sim with a focus on creative problem-solving.

It's got sprawling levels with different paths - and just like levels, problems can also be approached in different ways. It's got a wide range of abilities to unlock that can open up new avenues to traverse and abuse the environment and its inhabitants. Sabotage or directly confront, turn robots against one another or sneak past everything unseen!

There are apparently also ways to bypass some of the main story missions, I know two ways exist to bypass one specific mission but I have not figured out how yet. For me, that's super exciting.

Story-wise it's not that unique, filled with some tired tropes, but it takes an interesting turn down the line. The voice acting is stellar (some of it voiced by the main dev himself, very impressive!)

Toss in a bucket-load of IT terminology and jokes, British humour and Doctor Who-esque designs and you've got yourself a slightly ugly but very charming game with a ton of S O V L and creativity.

I love that the keybindings are tailored for PC and themed according to the game, ie to go into "control mode" to select a robot to inhabit, you do it by pressing "CTRL" on your keyboard! Similarly, CTRL+Home makes you control your primary robot. The ability "Shift" is triggered by your "Shift" key. This is so so brilliant! (Of course you could play this with a gamepad but WHY WOULD YOU?!)

I almost finished the game, but I didn't like my build and choices I made so I restarted from scratch and really loved replaying it. I have never ever done this before, and I also never replay games, but this game was even more enjoyable the second time around, because understanding the design language of the game allowed me to notice opportunities I had not before, and abuse the mechanics to their full potential. My second time with the game has been phenomenal, and the last two levels really blew my mind (in my first run I quit just before them!)

This is one of the rarer games that use achievement descriptions as a way to pique player interest and encourage them to do unusual things, for example there is an achievement that suggests an alternate way of completing a mission objective, and another implies that there is a way to bypass a segment of a seemingly mandatory story segment.

If you like to be creative, like imsims, British humour, IT jokes, robots, sci-fi, Doctor Who, Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy or any combination thereof, this game is for you. Just don't forget to bring your smarts.

Évaluation publiée le 25 mai 2023
Ctrl Alt Ego Is One Of The Better Gaming Experiences I've Had In Recent Memory

With its fair amount of uniqueness and quickness, the only way I can describe this piece is as the aftermath of a rough, drunk, unprotected sex session between a puzzle game like Portal and a sci-fi immersive sim like Prey. It's the most 'immsimmy' immersive sim game on the market, if that makes any sense. The player creativity here is equal to none – so great that, in some aspects, it's even a sandbox game of some sort.The puzzle-like structure here is top-notch too; it's consistent throughout the whole experience, and the fact that it's infused with some sandbox elements just adds to the almost infinite ways you can deal with each scenario. Whether it's going hog-wild on some robot enemies or actually using your brain and controlling them with EGO, which brings me to the next topic in my review: the game mechanics. Ctrl Alt Ego's combat consists of basic tools like a teleportation device, a shotgun, and even a vacuum cleaner (it's the absolute best tool, believe me). But most importantly, the EGO system sets this game apart. In this game, you control an entity that can hijack the body of any electronic device in the game by using a currency called EGO. By hijacking enemies, you can open up an infinite amount of player approach options for any scenario in each level.To this day, I still can't grasp the fact that this masterclass was made by only two (but incredible) individuals. I cannot recommend it enough, and if you're reading this, please go and support this awesome project – it's truly one of a kind.
Rating: 10/10, it's incredible

Évaluation publiée le 30 mai 2023
For a 1-2 man passion project, Ctrl Alt Ego is an incredible achievement. It's janky in parts, sure, and the performance isn't great, but it's a full length game with quality that actually IMPROVES the further in you get, and the sort of level design and systemic gameplay that makes it truly deserve its Immersive Sim label. Not only that, it actually innovates on classic imm sim design in a meaningful and unique way with its ego hopping mechanic, instead of simply imitating what came before it. (Not that I have any issue with that, mind - we could certainly do with more games that do a good job at aping the classics!)

As with most of these games, I strongly recommend turning off the floating objective markers. As with Prey and Dishonored and Deathloop, exploring the environment is a key part of the experience, and reducing your experience to chasing floating icons does the game a huge disservice. The game world is clearly designed with a lot of care and consideration, and I never found myself frustrated or completely disoriented.

I would have loved to see more types of robots with unique movement styles to possess instead of relying on Bug 22 and hopping between static machines so much, but I can't fault the devs for not adding even more features to an already packed game. Ctrl Alt Ego is up there with the big budget greats, and I hope MindThunk can continue making games like this in the future.

Évaluation publiée le 3 octobre 2022
I don't know where to begin with this. I've been holding off writing a review because I didn't have the words to describe how addicting and incredible this is. Ctrl Alt Ego is a hidden gem, and criminally underrated. This is a true immersive sim that sits right up there with some of the classics such as Thief, Prey 2017 and Dishonored in the way it feels playing it, while having its own unique mechanics.

There are many, many ways to approach a situation. There is plenty of room for emergent gameplay.. Every dead end has a solution. Every seemingly sealed off room has a way in.

With only a 2-person team, it's astonishing how much level of IMAGINATION it takes to write or design something like this. There's plenty of "aha" moments, and the game feels long, but by the time it ends, it leaves you wanting more.

The writing is smart, punny, endearing. A delightful charm from beginning to the end, leaving a wide grin from ear to ear. The game feels like a cute puzzle game at first, but eventually gets ponderous, existential, darker, stepping a little towards survival horror at times. The funny messages become cryptic, serious, and even heartbreaking. The lore is only there if you seek it out. There is plenty of fodder for lore-essay youtubers to sink their teeth into.

Best of all, the developer Mindthunk is incredibly active in engaging with the community, and continues to refine and update this even as of writing. We need more games like this in the genre. Steam's "Immersive Sim" tag has far too many non-immersive sims drowning it.

We need more youtubers to cover this than just Charlatan Wonder. Send this to Civvie 11, Boulder Punch, SuperHorrorBro, MandaloreGaming, Joseph Anderson. If you played this game and enjoyed it, please leave a review so that it gets up in the rankings.

26.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 novembre 2022
TL;DR

+ 20+ hours long, including some "bonus", modified campaign missions (worth the money!)
+ Definite replay value (it's an immersive sim!)
+ It's an immersive sim! (I'm a little biased here)
+ Made by two (2) people! Pretty impressive scope!
+ Solid, in-depth mechanics. Suits all play styles!
+ Very open-ended game play. Emergent game play up the wazoo! Play how you want!
+ Great overall concept
+ Fantastic level design, audio design
+ Solid enemy AI
+ Great narrative (often very tongue-in-cheek)

- Visual aesthetic is a little rough and may take some getting used to (not necessarily a big negative, except for "muh graphics" crowd)
- Some slight janky Unity physics shenanigans
- Plot twist is a bit cliche, or a trope, in that spoiler in the long part!, although it does tie up the narrative nicely.



FFO:

Prey (2017)
Deus Ex series
Outer Wilds
Gloomwood
Half Life (or really anything by Valve; Portal, Gmod, etc.)



THE LONG PART

I almost can't believe this game was made by 2 people! I'm so glad the developer replied to a Dave Oshry (I think) Twitter ♥♥♥♥ post, because this is a fantastic indie immersive sim!

While initially seeming to be a little rough around the edges, and the controls admittedly took a little time to get used to, the prologue gives a great impression, and after that, the rest of the game opens up for a truly wonderful approach to allowing the player to do whatever they want to reach the objective.

This game was about $30 AUD, and I think this is absolutely worth the price! There's 15-20 hours worth of levels for the campaign/story mode, with a couple more of some standalone, modified versions of a couple campaign missions. It seems like the developer is planning to add more of these challenges, so as of November 3 2022, stay tuned? There is also obvious replay value here, which involves changing the difficulty, or trying a different play style/upgrade.

The mechanics heavily rely on the emphasis on player choice, and the overall scope of the game entitles the player to figure out how to get from point A to B almost entirely on their own. This includes the choice of equipment upgrades, exploring the environment, handling enemies, and so on. While the game does give diegetic hints, or encourages the player to perform a specific task, these moments are few and far between.

The concept for the game's world is pretty good, and ties in nicely to the game mechanics. It's almost self-aware in some respects, especially in regard to the fact that the game is an immersive sim, and im-sims typically have terrible "boss fights" and endings. (No, it does NOT mention "looking glass" or "0451", as far as I saw. Maybe it should lose points for this?!) The narrative is spun along by a literal voice in a box, and as it unfolds, I start asking more questions as a mysterious series of events, and a conspiracy, comes to light. I did find it a little cliche at a certain point, and it is frankly a pretty obvious twist to guess, in that the player, deuteragonist, and antagonist are all versions of the same person within the simulation. But this doesn't detract from the experience at all.

The level design is immaculate for a game of this scope! It is so well fleshed out and open-ended, I am left wondering how long it took for these two devs to get out of the design phase. As the chapters progress, the levels get more complicated, and even more non-linear in design. There's even a few neat tricks thrown in, where I am blown away when I figure out how to clear the obstacle. Audio design is great; plenty of ambient, incidental music, different objects sound different, and enemies sufficiently click and/or whistle to let the player know their general location.

Enemy AI is very good. In this type of game, enemies should react to nearby sounds, certain movements, and be sufficiently capable of guarding the area they are in. Enemies in this game are good at their job, basically. Until, of course, you take control and assimilate them into your consciousness. Or shoot them. Or sneak past them. Or blow them up. Look, there's lots of ways to "husk" or be "husked" in this game. In short, if they see you, they get bothered (literally), and spend some time pondering your existence before returning to their default state, if you leave their field of view. If they do get sufficiently concerned (again, literally), they will do everything in their power to remove you from the equation. Some enemies have their unique quirks which the player will have to deal with, including collecting an access card, or spawning more enemies upon defeat.

Overall, this is a fantastic game, I just had to leave a long-winded, formatted review here. Highly recommended. I love my immersive sims, and I'm loving this im-sim "renaissance" we're having. First Prey 2017, then Gloomwood, now this? These are super niche types of games, or should be, but they are exploding in popularity.

Here's to this developer making a solid game, and to more unique titles to come!

Évaluation publiée le 2 aout 2022
A very creative and unique entry to the immersive sim category. It is more of a puzzle solving game than a straight shooter. It does provide the tools to go in guns blazing, but you would be missing a lot of what makes the game interesting.

The puzzles themselves ask for a good bit of exploration and creativity to solve (or bypass). The resources feel very rewarding to find, and gaining a new ability or upgrade feels immediately and obviously useful rather than a decision you can only hope will be good later. The story is charming, if a bit sidelined. It's nice to have an immersive sim that does not feel incredibly grim for once :)

The UI/UX is incredibly intuitive and well thought-out. The (unintended) bugs are minimal for me so far, and the game runs better than the specs would have you believe.

My main nitpick is that the visual design can be a bit... unattractive at times, especially with the main controllable robots. Not a deal breaker by any means, but it can be off putting before the gameplay distracts from it.

20.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 mai 2023
I honestly feel like this is what Watchdogs should've been. This is an ingenious blend of hacking, stealth, exploration, and some light role-playing. Don't expect a non-linear narrative. Expect non-linear levels with countless solutions to complete objectives and navigate safely. It's shockingly deep. You play as a disembodied EGO with the ability to jump from device to device whether it's a robot, a camera or an MP3 player. You can go as far as navigating entire levels without ever taking control of a bot. Numerous abilities are unlockable and upgradable like invisibility, telekinesis, a jetpack, a shotgun, grenades, etc. which each encourage a playstyle that the player is free to choose from. You'll never be forced to play any one way. Wanna go guns blazing? Go ahead. Wanna sneak through vents and sneak by while invisible? Knock yourself out. Wanna hack into a DAD bot to dematerialize any enemies around without having to risk losing your BUG bot? By all means, do it. This game greatly rewards the player's ingenuity and abilities are completely optional. You can get through every level without using any of your abilities. That's good game design. Despite how overwhelming it may all seem, the controls are very simple to understand and everything is explained clearly. Just hold Ctrl and then left click the thing you want to hack into. Even when there's a lot of hackable devices around you, you can easily set a filter for only specific types of devices making it easier to jump to the device your targeting. The game throws PLENTY of hints your way on how to progress. Arguably too many hints. Nonetheless, this is founded on experimentation and is more of a stealth puzzle game than a FPS. There's only one gun and it handles dreadfully. Don't expect strong presentation here. Environments are visually identical with more or less the same enemies over and over again. There are no cutscenes THANKFULLY. The story is told through audio logs and readable notes. The narrative goes in a much more humorous direction and it is very British. The voice acting for Dr. Everyman is great. Props there. I also have to compliment the excellent soundtrack which reminded me of Kraftwerk a bit. The performance of the game is more mixed. The game is clearly having to process a lot and the performance tanks in busier environments especially when going to hack. There's also numerous bugs (no pun intended). I've glitched out of the level entirely numerous times. Even enemies do it sometimes. It's not game-breaking as it is preventable, but expect a lot of jank in a game as highly ambitious, but still indie as this. The camera can be nauseating for one thing since this game simulates a 3D body in first person. Movement is floaty, intentionally, since your Bug hovers around. It takes some getting used to. Climbing stairs is especially headache inducing. Every mission is highly replayable and customizable. It can easily take at least an hour to fully explore every nook and cranny of the level. You feel like a genius when you overcome a difficult section through your own creativity. I appreciate devs encouraging players to engage in the systems they program into the game instead of holding our hand and telling us what to do. This is a strong recommendation from me. If I had to score it, I'd give it an 8/10.

44.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 juillet 2022
I've been watching this game development status on twitter for quite some time. It's concept of mind control and jumping between entities is a great one for a puzzle game, bringing back memories of the Abe's Odyssey series about prop hunt games. Despite this great gameplay idea I was concerned about how this would work in practice. Now I have my hands on the game I know I didn't need to worry! The transition between entities is smooth and it's simple to understand and it's very easy to get into playing around with the movement to explore your locations. The only warning I would add is that it may cause issues for people with motion sickness so maybe there could be an option were the transitions are simplified or removed?
The developer needs to get particular praise for the lack of hand-holding and direction in exploring and solving the puzzles. Go completely the wrong way and you get a simple prompt to "return to area X", but otherwise go ahead and wander around. Sneak? Sure. Destructive progress? Fine. Fly over obstacles? Blow them up? Hey. play to your style and pick the skills you want, it's all good.
Lastly, humour. I thoroughly enjoyed the puns and voice over and the little snippets of info on the datapads. IMHO quality humour in a puzzle game like this is a massive plus.
Overall this game is clearly a labour of love. MindThunk have come up with a brilliant puzzle game concept and now they just want the player to have fun in their world. A wonderful indiedev title.

What a wonderful game. I played this twice, back to back I loved it so much, rummaging around every corner to find every secret passage, power up and lore drop.

38.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 septembre 2022
You are "Ego", some kind of consciousness that can move between every machine, computer and robot in your line of sight. You don't know why or how, but you are about to find out!

Every machine you transfer into gives you full control over it. If you move into a computer, you can access its sensitive data. You can move into a door to unlock it. Move into a bomb to detonate it.. and so on. There's also several kinds of robots with different sets of skills and tools you can transfer between as you progress.

There's so many ways to solve problems; You can be sneaky, you can place traps, you can manipulate the enemy, install useful software or devastating hacks, or use brute force. You can't even die! If you fail and your machine breaks, just transfer into another and try another route. With that said, it can still be very challenging at times.

This game is a pure and almost childish joy!

Highly recommended.

Évaluation publiée le 14 aout 2022
Thoroughly enjoyable immersive sim!!!

Found the story to be pleasant and overall rewarding for working through the game. The art and music were both charming and quite fitting. Really enjoyed the main bug model.

The game play was pretty darn good if you were playing a little slower/stealthy. There were decent number of routes and lots helpful objects/data/keys. The game felt pleasing on a gut level when you solve a puzzle, and clever when you find a quicker route. For the most part you don't wander too blindly with sufficient quest markers and in game signage. I might have put a few more, but you get quite a lot of hints and helpful pointers throughout the game. The skill system was adequate, but the skills themselves were very good with each one having distinct uses/play styles. You can get a quite a few skills and skill points if you are thorough.

Not all peaches and cream. I hated having to carry anything through a tube or pick up the grill plates blocking them. There is a little bit of jank, and it got me killed a few times. Pacing, there is a slightly too slow build up for an end that overstays. I liked the difficulty spikes, but they could be rough on the first play through. I would not want to play the game without the float skill.

really enjoyed it overall even after a few frustrating parts

Évaluation publiée le 7 décembre 2022
This is a very fun, unique, interesting, and creative immersive sim that falls into all the usual shortcomings that immersive sims are known to have!
Combat becomes easier than stealth around the mid-game and never does stealth catch up to combat in its ease. The final boss is piss-easy. It's quite possible to soft-lock yourself in many scenarios and circumstances, and if you make too much accidental forward progress it becomes nearly impossible to go back and see where that particular option soft-locks.

The story is nothing to write home about. The enemies are repetitive. The puzzles are exquisite, and that immersive sim *feeling* of wading through a room, half in stealth, half violently cleaning up anyone who spots you or your path, is strong here. It's very, very satisfying.

I'd say this is a real quality 7/10. Closer to an 8 than a 6.

13.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 octobre 2022
Ctrl Alt Ego is one of the best concepts imaginable developed by the least competent people imaginable.

It's playable ENTIRELY on the strength of its concept, even as it attempts to bungle the execution of it at every possible turn.

The pitch is that you are a disembodied mind that jumps from device to device as you try to disable/avoid the facility's guardians and eventually do... something vague that I kind of missed. When possessing your "primary" form, the BUG, you also get some special powers that are liberally lifted from Dishonored, Prey, etc. there's nothing original there but it's all stand-bys of the genre it attempts to be.

See, that's another thing to address. I've seen people call this an immersive sim, I think even some of the marketing material does, but it isn't. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ aside, an immersive sim is about being in a believable environment that you can see as something other than a gameplay level, as a work environment, lab or living space, and then interacting with believable things. The environments in CAE are more like Portal levels. This isn't to say this is bad by itself, I loved Portal and Portal 2, I just feel like it misrepresents what the game is.

Anyway, this all sounds pretty good so far, right?

Well too bad, they screwed it up.

Firstly, you've got a game that often involves physics manipulations where the physics are awful. Even while doing something as simple as riding an elevator, your possessed item will attempt to topple over. Physics objects regularly block necessary items. Carried objects will occasionally simply choose to clip outside of the level. Sometimes you carry something and it just explodes in your face.

Secondly, the UI is designed in some sort of very specialized circle of Hell. Possessing something always leaves you looking at a wall or similar, no matter how the object is otherwise facing, and any time there are two vaguely approximate objects to possess, it's suffering to make sure the game picks the right one. You also generally possess machines that are about two feet tall, and have to get items out of containers that are three feet tall, forcing you to battle the camera and sometimes jump on top of and into the container just to get things out of it.

Pointless possessions. You have to possess buttons to press them, and notepads to read them(while oddly enough you can read stationary computer screens just fine by walking up to them), and a number of other such pointlessly fiddly things. There are plenty of buttons in the game you just PUSH, and then piles of them that you have to possess, flipping around your PoV and making it clunky to get back to where you started. This sucks and is bad. You can't even skip some of these because even the pure "lore" items provide EGO which is one of the game's important power usage "currencies."

The game wants you to do stealth, but you're piloting something with a 50-degree FoV and all the acrobatic prowess of a beached sea cucumber, which means that even if you plot the perfect heist, you're going to get held up against a juicebox or a screwdriver.

All this comes together in a way that makes the game feel even when you're doing things right, like you're doing things wrong. Oh and I also hit one puzzle that I think is legitimately impossible without glitching it out with the right powers(which you may or may not have, still, optional puzzle) since the bot you're supposed to possess to navigate a maze can't navigate the maze, or possibly it's just that you may softlock the maze by opening a box in the wrong order.

Plus just, a bunch of other small annoying bugs like a door that resets to closed every time you reach it, and then the first time each time you press the open button it re-closes again immediately afterwards.

Lastly, but not least, there is one(1) voiced character in this game, who is omnipresent, and they found possibly the least charismatic person imaginable for this important starring role. I wanted to brain him with a wrench from the first sentence, I would rather just have read text entries than deal with that.

So long story short: It's INCREDIBLY sad that they executed the game as badly as they did, because it had WILD amounts of potential. Do better next time, maybe do even a marginal amount of beta-testing.

Évaluation publiée le 28 mars 2023
As soon as I started playing it I knew I messed up.

Prey is my favorite game, so I bought this on the dozens of recommendations that said it was similar. What in the world are people talking about? Nothing about this game is similar to Prey in the slightest.

The graphics and physics are extremely, what's the word... cheap and unrealistic. The "immersion" is just point A to point B puzzles for the sake of being puzzles. Nothing about this game is enthralling, thought-provoking, or attention grabbing. It's like a (very) low-budget cross between Portal and The Stanley Parable, but less fun and significantly less aesthetically pleasing. I've drunkenly created more attractive environments in 30 minutes using 1999's Unreal Editor.

The difference between Prey and this game is the difference between me paying any amount of money for a game, and wishing I had stubbed my toe instead of playing it.

This game might have a great concept, but it's so under-cooked that it's painful to have it on my computer. I've already requested a refund and uninstalled it and nothing anyone says can convince me to reverse course.

I mean absolutely no disrespect to the humble, creative team who made this unique game, but the fans (maybe friends of the developers or even the developers themselves on alt accounts?) who are talking so highly about it aren't doing it any favors in the long run. Just give it a fully honest critique and please leave Prey out of your mouth.

And... run it by someone before calling it finished and putting it out there. My 2 cents.

Évaluation publiée le 5 janvier
Was a pretty fun game overall. Obviously this is not a AAA immersive sim like the neo-deus ex games or dishonoured, etc, but it certainly carries on their spirit even if it can't match all of their breadth. There's definitely good depth to this game, but a lot of its depth lies in sort of "pushing against the simulation". so to speak. Doing things that almost don't feel intended, but are.

Pure stealth is much harder and possibly more boring than Deus Ex or Dishonoured but I don't think that's entirely a bad thing- those two games end up being more stealth games than anything else, whereas here it's much more up to you how to approach things. It almost gave me the feeling of a VR game like bonelabs, where you're just interacting with the environment without feeling like there's a way you "should" be playing the game, and a lot of people will have different experiences.

All in all, I'd recommend it. It was a good time, though I am not sure I'll replay it, partially because of how easily I got everything. Definitely a sleeper gem, though!

I'm going to tell you a bit about my experience with this game.

It all started with my love for Prey and looking for other immersive sym games for me to play. While looking at Dillon Rogers twitter (X) due to him developing the game I'm most excited about, I saw that he was recommending some games, one of them had a fantastic cover art that immediately caught my eye and I decided to look for it on Steam. With just 300 reviews I decided to buy it as soon as I could get a chance.

What comes after that is a great and possibly the most immersive and most impressive game I have played in a long time. It wasn't all positive at first, I tried the game for around 8 hours first, reaching the Chapter 6 and considering that it was extremely hard and even if I liked the concept of the game and mechanics that maybe it wasn't for me and that was ok. I decided to give it another chance after a couple of weeks, I restarted my playthrough and, for some unknown reason even to me, decided to up the challenge and play it on Strict. During these 21 hours (11.5 in game time) I had an amazing time and it was all due to having a different perspective on how to overcome the situations. On my first playthrough I was playing it like a shooter, getting the gun.exe first and basically shooting my way through those first six chapters and some stealth sprinkled through there. On the second playthrough I found different paths, different ways to unlock doors, hack through stuff, fly through the level being the best bodyless EGO I could be and I loved each second of it.

This game is the purest definition of a hidden gem that I have ever seen, I'm not that into making written reviews of games I just want more people to find this game and experience this incredible game.

If my review wasn't clear enough on how much I LOVE this game, or maybe you just want a quick score: 10/10.

Évaluation publiée le 27 octobre 2023
**heavy British accent*

Ah, you've got a discerning taste in gaming, I must say.

Ctrl Alt Ego takes that essence-switching mechanic from Geist and blasts it into orbit. The game offers that same thrill of embodying different entities, but now you're doing it in a richly crafted space station, dialed up to eleven.

Like Geist, Ctrl Alt Ego isn't just playing a game, it's a tactical switch of perspectives. It captures that blend of high-stakes action and psychological gameplay, but the setting and humor give it a uniquely British spin. For you, it's not just a sequel to a beloved concept; it's an evolution.

The future you liked in "Geist" is fully realized here in "Ctrl Alt Ego." This is not just another title; it's a paradigm shift.


ASCII art of Peter Molyneux:

____
/ \
| 0 0 |
\ ^ /
\___/


**End transmission**
 
SirCoKane vs the World
260 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
17.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 octobre 2023
No meio de uma indústria muito saturada onde todos os novos jogos são mais do mesmo (até no cenário indie nota-se certa estagnação também), é muito legal descobrir um jogo divertido e criativo que consegue apresentar algo totalmente novo, partindo de uma premissa já existente. Esse jogo é o Ctrl Alt Ego.

Ctrl Alt Ego é um Simulador Imersivo filosófico com alto foco na resolução de problemas e exploração para encontrar meios diversos para concluir o mesmo objetivo. Nele, controlamos um “ego sem corpo” que, a partir da orientação de um estranho indivíduo conhecido como Doutor Everyman, devemos destruir um parasita que se alimenta do ego de outros robôs. Não apenas isso, mas descobrir também o que aconteceu com a estação espacial, com o doutor, e descobrir quem somos.

Sendo um ego sem corpo, o jogador pode se mover livremente pelos locais controlando (se teleportando em) outros dispositivos para descobrir novos pontos de interesse e meios de alcançar os objetivos. Controle câmeras e veja a área ao redor, controle portas e elevadores para liberar novos locais, controle robôs agressivos como os PAIs e as MÃEs, ou controle cachorrinhos inofensivos e passe despercebido por eles. Há uma grande variedade de dispositivos que é possível controlar que abrem novas possibilidades para a jogatina, mas claro, desde que tenha ego o suficiente para controlar eles.

Aliada a essa liberdade de controlar outros dispositivos, os jogadores terão também a sua disposição o Bug-22, um bot que foi banido (assim como todos os Bugs) que é capaz de instalar programas em si que expandem as possibilidades de jogatina, sendo alguns deles o programa de vôo, de ficar invisível, de teleporte, de imprimir novos objetos, ou de equipar uma escopeta. No entanto, como os bugs foram banidos, o Bug-22 é alvo fácil para outros robôs agressivos e sistemas de alarme, mas não se preocupe, pois não é possível perder em Ctrl Alt Ego. Se você perder seu Bug-22 de alguma forma, você sempre pode reimprimir ele nas estações apropriadas.

Por ser um Simulador Imersivo, o jogador é livre para pôr a criatividade em prática para resolver os problemas da forma que achar mais conveniente, e isso é reforçado pelo próprio jogo em uma mensagem em um tablet, que diz que não existe jeito certo ou errado de jogar, que há diferentes rotas e meios de concluir um objetivo, e que é possível fazer uma bagunça, e mesmo assim ficar tudo bem. Se em algum momento o jogador achar que “fez algo errado”, é para parar de achar isso imediatamente, pois tudo o que o jogador fez ou pode fazer é totalmente intencional.

Partindo para outros aspectos, o jogo possui uma estética geral inspirada em um futuro distópico representado nos programas britânicos de TV dos anos 70, com seus ambientes futuristas coloridos e iluminados, e robôs e dispositivos com aparência, nomes, descrições e sons engraçados. A trilha sonora é minimalista e divertida, combina perfeitamente com o jogo. Graficamente, o jogo é ok, no entanto ela casa perfeitamente com a estética do jogo, mostrando assim um jogo bem agradável de ver.

Se tratando de bugs (não, não os robôs, dessa vez são bugs mesmo) eu encontrei bem poucos, e nenhum deles chegou a atrapalhar a jogatina. O jogo tem uma boa otimização, mas fica notoriamente pesado no último capítulo, onde o local é gigante e tem muita coisa acontecendo ao mesmo tempo. No geral, deve rodar em qualquer coisa (se rodou no meu I5 de terceira geração, deve rodar no seu PC sem problemas).

No geral, Ctrl Alt Ego é um divertido jogo inovador e adequado para todos os perfis de jogadores, desde crianças a adultos, jogadores veteranos ou casuais, fãs ou não de Simuladores Imersivos ou Puzzles, e isso a um preço condizente com o conteúdo entregue. Uma experiência diferenciada e obrigatória!

P.S. Um aspecto importante que deve ser mencionado: Gatos - O nome dos computadores no jogo é CAT (Ctrl Alt Terminal) com arte "ASCII" de gatos neles, as câmeras de selfie sempre tiram fotos de gatos, e as imagens das conquistas também só tem gatos. Gatos em todos os lugares. Isso sozinho já faz o jogo valer totalmente a pena :D

Évaluation publiée le 26 octobre 2023
Maybe the best immersive sim I've ever played.

This game poses interesting philosophical questions on the nature of thought and being, it provides numerous solutions to every situation (box stacking, violence, stealth, 'hacking' in the form of control, other kinds of violence, teleportation), and it is truly immersive and draws you in to look at every detail / examine every nook and cranny / engage all of your senses (except smell and taste, thank God). It has a good sense of humor as well!

The final thing I'll praise about the game is something that is hard to get right in immersive sims and that is a sense of stakes; in games like Prey or Deus Ex you don't want to die and there is a tremendous amount of tension and frustration when you do die. You're tied to a character and their fate is important to you. What I'm trying to say is that being a ball of pure consciousness is a huge relief! There ARE stakes... you do WANT to pull off well executed moves... but also there aren't because destruction off whatever body you're in at the time means nothing. The premise of the game allows this to be believable... so it isn't immersion breaking. If you were to take all the tension and stakes out of Prey, it wouldn't make any sense and would in itself break immersion. Honestly, my one fault for another recent immersive sim, Shadows of Doubt, is that sometimes it feels like there are no stakes when they should exist in the setting.

If you are like me and sometimes you have to stop playing other immersive sims because the tension is too much and you REALLY just wanted to relax and play a game, then this is for you. If you crave a challenge THIS GAME IS ALSO FOR YOU. You can dial the difficulty waaaay up and try for other difficult goals.

Really, I cannot think of any downsides to this game. The developer is super responsive in the Steam forums and is clearly a person who understands what is truly enjoyable about immersive sims as a genre.

I'd love to see a fusion of Ctrl Alt Ego and Shadows of Doubt!!! What a masterpiece that would be. Anyway, buy this game now!

Update: I started playing through the missions... they are also extremely well done! These are unique scenarios that offer very specific challenges. Each one feels like a chess puzzle: there is a solution to each scenario, even on the hardest difficulties, so long as you are observant and not too wasteful of the limited resources available. I thought I was done with the game, but after challenging myself to beat Advanced Rocket Surgery on Severe (which I did in just over 10 minutes before work) I feel like my interest is renewed and I'm looking forward to the remaining missions!

Évaluation publiée le 22 octobre 2023
Ctrl Alt Ego is awesome. If you enjoy immersive sims or puzzle solving, I think this is a must-buy. It feels sort of like Prey, Portal, and Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy mixed together.

You play a disembodied ego on a space station. While you do have one main body that you use and upgrade, you can possess most of the enemies in the game, and you can also possess things like doors, tiny machines, security systems, and more. Things that have some level of security on them cost ego to possess, whereas the small things like pads or oscilloscopes tend to give you ego when you possess them. This gives you an absurd amount of freedom to solve the puzzles in this game - you could just run in and corrupt various objects into explosives and throw them around, or you could hop around possessing objects to figure out how to stealthily move through a room, or you could just use your excess ego to possess all of the guards in the room and make it a friendly space for you to move through, or you could just skip that room altogether and find a printer on the other side to teleport your body around it. It's pretty crazy how many solutions each room has and how much freedom you have to figure out your own solution.

There is a pretty big difficulty spike near the end of the game, but as long as you've been thorough in your exploration and collected a good number of upgrades, you'll be fine. Even then, I get the notion that you'd be fine if you just played creatively and slowly. It seems difficult to hit a fail state, as there's a lot of ways to do things.

Definitely pick this up if you enjoy immersive sims or puzzle solving.

A hidden gem that truly stands out from the abundance of indie games. Ctrl Alt Ego is an immersive sim that stands on its own feet through a primary game mechanic I have not seen before which makes it feel fun, and original. If you like to play games your way where there are multiple ways of going about achieving the task set out for you then this should be right up your alley. The dev is very competent at writing and crafting an interesting game world. This game also has immense replay-ability due to how many skills and upgrades are available. My only regret is that I didn't do my first play through on hard - that was a mistake as it was bit too easy which made me lazy when it came to strategy as guns blazing was an easy option.

This game is fantastic and worth every penny at full price.

Évaluation publiée le 5 septembre 2023
Highly recommended. If you like immersive sims, appreciate British humour, and were annoyed when Maplins, Radio Shack or your local equivalent closed down, then this is for you. By definition it is an immersive sim; a shooter when you want it to be, or a stealth game, or a puzzle game, in whatever proportions suit you.

Ctrl Alt Ego takes a "fail forward" approach to death, in which each defeat is only a minor reset, losing no progress and never leaving the game world, something developers have attempted using various methods since the first Prey. Eventually players will realise that there is no need to save or reload, except to start and end a session. In this sense, Ctrl Alt Ego achieves what Know By Heart set out to do, which is to encourage the player to accept failure, which here is used as a means to learn and continue rather than a series of one-way decisions. Even when you're out of juice, have made a mess and reprinted your robot twenty times, there is always a solution, and this is where the real fun of the game lies. Levels are intricately designed with routes and bypasses to discover, so there's often something else to try.

The plot of the game is well-delivered, using the familiar tools of disembodied voice (which is disembodied for an in-game reason), convenient journal entries and environmental design. Players are strongly encouraged to read everything, as in Control, the narrative is the sum of each part, which builds into a convincing whole.

Again, highly recommended.

The game is free to a fault, where obstacles act less like obstacles and more like suggestions on what you might not want to do for most of the game — you can pretty much trivialise every level by possessing an enemy, and running through with invisibility when needed.

The gameplay and world-building are top-notch im-sim stuff, but I found that the pacing of the game dragged around halfway through, and it only really got better when I further upgraded my character to completely trivialise the actual challenges, so the game became more about exploring the station at my own pace than actively struggling to make it through.

Overall, this game feels more like an exploration sandbox than most other immersive simulators, making me disengage at times, but it really has no major flaws in my mind, and I would recommend it to anyone who would find this intriguing based on its Steam page.

Reina Weis
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
28.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 mai 2023
Great immersive sim that is incredibly creative.

It kind of falls into the same pitfalls as some other immersive sims like Prey in that enemy and weapon (not ability) variety is somewhat limited, but they do a great job with what they do have. There are a lot of ways to deal with most situations in the game, whether it be stealth, combat, or variations inbetween.

Want to directly shoot/drill things yourself, and then vacuum up the parts to refill your health'/ammo? Sure.
Want to cloak/teleport around and avoid everything, or move right in front of them using an unsuspecting "allied" robot you've taken over? Go for it.
Want to amass a pile of ego and take over your enemies (or even spawn your own), and defeat everything using a sort of laser shooting proxy army? You bet.
Hell, you want to run up to an enemy, turn them into a bomb, and then chuck/shift them across the room into everyone else, or let that bomb infect everyone else and turn them into bombs too? You bet you can do that.

The enemies are really weird in that way too; some are 3D printers that don't destroy a target, but store them, and if you take them over you can re-place them. Some turn enemies into weightless husks that can be re-energized using health, allowing you use that enemy to move them wherever you like (chucking them into a room perhaps), re-energizing them using another robot, and preparing to destroy everything from there while they are considered non-hostile as you teleport ammo/juice to them using download. Unfortunately, as mentioned there are only a few real enemies; if there is a sequel in the future, hopefully this number is increased (maybe doubled?).

It plays a lot more like a puzzle game then other immersive sims do, in that there are a lot of optional situations that you can solve by thinking carefully about your abilities, but if you mess up the puzzle you can't fix it. Thankfully if you mess these optional puzzles up then you don't lose out (notably with disks/new ability unlocks, as there are more then enough disks in the game to unlock them all, even if you can't come even close to upgrading them all with all worms. Plus saving is infinite and save points are always near-by these, so just make sure to save often if you aren't willing to leave anything behind.

If you are into immersive sims (shooters, stealth games, or maybe even puzzle games), I fully recommend this.

Ctrl Alt Ego might be one of my favorite "immersive-sims" at the moment.

It's heavily influenced by System Shock and Prey (2017), but is also quite different in that it has less of an emphasis on "conventional" combat and more on alternative approaches and general problem solving.

In a lot of ways Ctrl Alt Ego feels like it's what you get if you grow an immersive sim from the starting point of a first person puzzle"game like Portal instead of from an FPS or RPG.

3.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 mars 2023
Ctrl Alt Ego

Drawn to 'Ctrl Alt Ego' for its immersive simulation, akin to favorites like Prey and Dishonored, I found myself in the midst of an experience that's more exploratory than traditional gameplay.

Pro:
+ Uniquely unusual game that offers a fresh experience.
+ The ego system and interactions with objects are innovative and engaging.

Contra:
- Challenging to get into due to the need for self-guided discovery and understanding.
- Controls could be improved for a better gameplay experience.
- Art direction and overall presentation fall short of expectations.
- Lacks guidance for players, making navigation and progression often confusing.
- While the system mechanics are interesting, the game misses the mark in worldbuilding compared to similar titles by studios like Arkane

Conclusion:
'Ctrl Alt Ego' is a GOOD game for those who enjoy experimentation and exploration within a unique framework.

Évaluation publiée le 1 mars 2023
Ctrl Alt Ego is one of the best examples of modern immersive sim design (think Deus Ex or Prey with more whimsy and creativity).
The gameplay is primarily comprised of open ended environments with a set objective. Where CAE excels is by not funneling the player into a set A, B or C path. The player is allowed to use their own ingenuity to solve the problems, and the further I got in the game the more I realized just how open those systems really are. It truly felt like my only limits were my own creativity.
Highly recommended for anyone that enjoys immersive sims, player driven mechanics, and sci-fi narratives. Plus, an absolute steal for the price

Évaluation publiée le 15 janvier 2023
I buy games fairly often and in all my years of gaming I haven't come across anything quite like this one before. This is a real gem that deserves a closer look rather than mistaking it for something it's not like I initially did.

To put it as simple as I can it's a puzzler where you control a robot on a space station trying to solve various tasks and progress to other areas as an omnious situation is occuring. There is no single intended or preset way to solve anything like you find in every other game. It's a laugh trying out different ideas or just wing it in a mundane way. Anything goes.

An important mechanic is that you can jump to and control different robots you see or devices that do different things. There's even upgrade disks and other stuff I've yet to find out about. There's tons of stuff on the station you can interact with and do things so many different ways this is a game I'm looking forward to replaying over and over.

If it at least sounds interesting try the demo as it's hard to describe, you need to experience it for yourself.
